lot_info.sDesc: LINCOLN READING THE EMANCIPATION PROCLAMATION. RITCHIE, ALEXANDER HAY, engraver. The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation. New York Francis Bicknell Carpenter, 1866.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
LINCOLN READING THE EMANCIPATION PROCLAMATION.
RITCHIE, ALEXANDER HAY, engraver.
The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation. New York: Francis Bicknell Carpenter, 1866.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
LINCOLN READING THE EMANCIPATION PROCLAMATION.
RITCHIE, ALEXANDER HAY, engraver. The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation. New York: Francis Bicknell Carpenter, 1866. Stipple engraving with hand coloring, 750 x 1016 mm, framed.
Exhibited: Abraham Lincoln: Railsplitter to Rushmore, The Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and Museum, Simi Valley, CA, 2013.

From a painting executed by Carpenter over the course of six months at the White House in 1864, and informed by interviews with Lincoln and sittings with the cabinet members. Surrounding Lincoln are Edwin M. Stanton, Salmon P. Chase, President Lincoln, Gideon Welles, Caleb B. Smith, William H. Seward, Montgomery Blair, and Edward Bates. The original painting is 15 feet long and hangs in the U.S. Capitol.

next_lot.desc: LINCOLN'S SUMMER WHITE HOUSE. MAGNUS, CHARLES (attributed). View from the Military Asylum, Washington. District of Columbia." c.1861.

lot_symbols.sLongDesc: Lot to be sold without reserve.

lot_info.sDesc: LINCOLN'S SUMMER WHITE HOUSE. MAGNUS, CHARLES (attributed). View from the Military Asylum, Washington. District of Columbia. c.1861.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
LINCOLN'S SUMMER WHITE HOUSE.
MAGNUS, CHARLES (attributed).
View from the Military Asylum, Washington. District of Columbia." c.1861.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
LINCOLN'S SUMMER WHITE HOUSE.
MAGNUS, CHARLES (attributed). View from the Military Asylum, Washington. District of Columbia." c.1861. Color lithograph, 240 x 305 mm, laid down to 115 x 185 mm mount lettered in gilt, framed.
Provenance: purchased from Ralph Newman (date unrecorded).

A period view from the vantage point of the U.S. Soldier's Home, formerly the Military Asylum, where Lincoln and his family spent their summers in 1862-63-64. Lincoln stayed in the Anderson Cottage during the hottest parts of the summer, as had Buchanan before him and Hayes and Arthur after. During his first summer living at the cottage, Lincoln drafted the Emancipation Proclamation.

lot_info.sDesc: FALL OF PETERSBURG. Grant's Petersburg Progress, vol. 1, no. 1.  Petersburg, VA Eden  McCreery, April 3, 1865.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
FALL OF PETERSBURG.
Grant's Petersburg Progress, vol. 1, no. 1. Petersburg, VA: Eden & McCreery, April 3, 1865.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
FALL OF PETERSBURG.
Grant's Petersburg Progress, vol. 1, no. 1. Petersburg, VA: Eden & McCreery, April 3, 1865.
Printed broadside, 470 x 303 mm, laid down to mount and framed to 715 x 610 mm.

The first issue of a rare Civil War-era newspaper celebrating the Union victory at Petersburg. The headline reads: "Petersburg Ours! We Are Here!! Hellelujah: Holiday for the Army. Great Rejoicing!"
The paper only ran through April 10 of 1865.

LINCOLN AS ATTORNEY.
Abraham Lincoln as Attorney for the Illinois Central Railroad Company. [Chicago]: Illinois Central Railroad Company, May 1905.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
LINCOLN AS ATTORNEY.
Abraham Lincoln as Attorney for the Illinois Central Railroad Company. [Chicago]: Illinois Central Railroad Company, May 1905.
Large quarto (308 x 230 mm). illustrated throughout with photogravures of Lincoln documents in the ICRC collection. Full limp black morocco lettered in gilt. Light age-toning to leaves, some light wear to fore-edge of binding. In clamshell box.
Provenance: Lou F. English (presentation page); Foreman M. Lebold (lettering to clamshell box).

LIMITED EDITION, number 6 of 14 copies in the Printer's Edition (out of a total of 200), this copy presented by Walter J. Gunthorp to Lou F. English.

lot_info.sDesc: A BRONZE LINCOLN BUST BY LEO CHERNE.  CHERNE, LEO, sculptor.  Abraham Lincoln. Inscribed (C) 1955 LEO CHERNE at base of neck.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
A BRONZE LINCOLN BUST BY LEO CHERNE.
CHERNE, LEO, sculptor.
Abraham Lincoln. Inscribed (C) 1955 LEO CHERNE at base of neck.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
A BRONZE LINCOLN BUST BY LEO CHERNE.
CHERNE, LEO, sculptor. Abraham Lincoln. Inscribed (C) 1955 LEO CHERNE at base of neck.
Height of sculpture 15 in (380 mm); overall height 21 in (532 mm).

Sculptor Leo Cherne was an economist, attorney, humanitarian, public servant and advisor to nine U.S. presidents. In 1955, he created a bust of President Abraham Lincoln based on a photograph taken in 1865, just hours after the White House learned of General Robert E. Lee's surrender and only four days before Lincoln was assassinated. (Lore has it that Lincoln was reciting the assassination lines from "Macbeth" while he sat for the photo.)

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
A GROUP OF HANDMADE CIVIL WAR FIGURES.
10 figures, each approx 16 in high (405 mm), featuring carved hands and faces, hand-sewn costumes, hand-fabricated shoes and accessories, and real hair, all mounted on individual wooden bases.
Provenance: purchased in Gettysburg, PA.

This charming collection of hand-made figures includes the following soldiers: "Confederate Cavalryman," "Union Prisoner of War" (amputee with crutch); "Union Black Infantryman," Union Professor Thaddeus Lowe with Binoculars," "Union Marine," " Confederate Infantry Officer," Union Duryea's Zouave," Confederate 1st Cherokee Mounted Rifle," Union Cavalryman," and "Confederate Louisiana Zouave."

4. HERTZ, EMANUEL, editor. Abraham Lincoln: The Tribute of the Synagogue. New York: Bloch Publishing Co., 1927. 4to. Half morocco over buckram. Limited edition, number 50 of 100, signed and inscribed by the author to Ralph G. Lindstrom, noted Lincoln scholar.

2. Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association. Fort Wayne, IN: 1979-2011. 8vo. Printed wrappers. Housed in 2 custom clamshell boxes, plus loose issues. Not a complete run.

A group of publications from the Abraham Lincoln Association, which was formed in 1908 as the Lincoln Centenary Association to celebrate Lincoln's hundredth birthday. The ALA remains the oldest and largest Lincoln association to date.

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
FROM THE COLLECTION OF LOUISE TAPER
A NATCHEZ, MISSISSIPPI "TOUR OF HOMES" ALBUM.
WRIGHT, R.B., compiler. Natchez Miss. Album of gelatin silver print photographs, each 232 x 290 mm (9 x 11.5 inches), laid down to album leaves, with manuscript gloss on opposite leaf, housed in green calf gilt album, upper cover detached but present.

With presentation inscription to Betty Hickey dated February 4, 1976 to front pastedown. Album includes photos of ante-bellum buildings and homes in Natchez, including Melrose, Briers, Holly Hedges, Burns, Dunleith, Stanton Hall, Monmouth, Monteigne, Linden, Elmscourt, Rosalie, D'Evereux, Auburn, Elms, Towers, and St. Mary's Cathedral, among others.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
A 48 STAR FLAG EMBROIDERY.
Patriotic hand-embroidery, after 1912,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
A 48 STAR FLAG EMBROIDERY.
Patriotic hand-embroidery, after 1912, in red, white, blue and brown silk on natural cotton broadcloth, 505 x 410 mm overall, folded, depicting an unfurled 45-star U.S. flag and stars-and-stripes streamer, over the inscription "O long may it wave. Dampstaining to center, fold creases, 60 mm tear near lower left edge, some fading to blue silk thread.

A patriotic embroidery, probably at one time housed in a frame to be placed in a window or on a mantel, dating from the period after Arizona and New Mexico were admitted to the Union.

next_lot.desc: ANBUREY, THOMAS. c.1760-1840. Travels Through the Interior Parts of America....   London: William Lane, 1789.

lot_info.sDesc: ANBUREY, THOMAS. c.1760-1840. Travels Through the Interior Parts of America....   London William Lane, 1789.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
ANBUREY, THOMAS. c.1760-1840.
Travels Through the Interior Parts of America.... London: William Lane, 1789.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
ANBUREY, THOMAS. c.1760-1840.
Travels Through the Interior Parts of America.... London: William Lane, 1789.
2 volumes. 8vo (204 x 128 mm). Half titles, folding map, and 8 engraved plates (5 folding). Contemporary boards, rebacked in modern calf antique. Spines sunned, corners bumped, browning and spotting, a few scattered stains, tear in lower margin of leaf H5 and repaired tear at lower margin of Dd2 in volume 1, small tear to top margin of leaf S3 in volume 2, old Parisian bookseller's labels on rear paste-downs.
Provenance: Harvard College Library, gift of Samuel A. Eliot (bookplate).

FIRST EDITION of this important travel account of Canada and the Northeast. Anburey began his travels in Newfoundland in the midst of the Revolutionary War, spending time in Quebec City and Montreal before crossing Lake Champlain to enter the United States, where he gives a lively account of the American Revolution from June 1777 to October 1781. Howes A226 ("aa"); Sabin 1366.

next_lot.desc: DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE. In Congress, July 4th 1776. The Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America. Washington: Benjamin Owen Tyler, 1818.

lot_info.sDesc: DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE. In Congress, July 4th 1776. The Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America. Washington Benjamin Owen Tyler, 1818.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE.
In Congress, July 4th 1776. The Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America. Washington: Benjamin Owen Tyler, 1818.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE.
In Congress, July 4th 1776. The Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America. Washington: Benjamin Owen Tyler, 1818.
Engraved broadside, 800 x 650 mm. Engraved by Peter Maverick after Benjamin Owen Tyler. 3 small marginal tears, not affecting text, small tape repair to upper corner, some staining.

THE EARLIEST PRINTED FACSIMILE of the Declaration of Independence, the founding document of the United States of America. Appearing on the market one year ahead of John Binns' facsimile, Tyler and Maverick's version with its finely engraved calligraphy and ornamented header stated that it was "Copied from the original ... in the Department of State and Published by Benjamin Owen Tyler, Professor of Penmanship...." It also included an endorsement from Secretary of State Benjamin Rush at the lower left. In the wake of the War of 1812, Americans felt a groundswell of patriotism, and the aging founding fathers and their legacy achieved greater reverence in the public consciousness. Tyler's order book, now in the Albert H. Small collection at the University of Virginia, bears the signatures of the first purchaser's of Tyler's work, including John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, John Quincy Adams, and others. John Adams, upon receiving his copy, wrote to Tyler that it was "elegantly and exquisitely executed...." Sold with the 9-volume American Archives (c.1843), in later cloth, and lacking the Peter Force Declaration.

lot_info.sDesc: GOLD RUSH ARCHIVE. A group of items relating to the California Gold Rush,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
GOLD RUSH ARCHIVE.
A group of items relating to the California Gold Rush,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
GOLD RUSH ARCHIVE.
A group of items relating to the California Gold Rush, including:
1. Charles and Leonori's New York Bank Note List. Volume XI, number 28. New York, Saturday, july 27, 1850. 4to (302 x 213 mm). 24 pp with advertisements on last page. Self-wrappers. Staining, foxing, fold creases, slight chipping to edges.
2. Four letters from I.P. Coates, esquire of Chicago to "Papa" in Fresno, California, 1880-1882, containing some mention of gold mining, gold ore, etc. All 4to, in ink on lined paper, with associated mailing envelopes
3. Three letters bearing wax seals embedded with gold dust, folded and addressed to three unrelated recipients, without franking.
WITH: An unrelated autograph document relating to a land lease between J.W. Bundren and Sarah Eagan, 3 pp verso and recto, 8vo bifolium, San Antonio, February 23, 1888, in ink on lined paper, with associated envelope, without franking, bearing the name of J.W. Bundren.
WITH: Membership certificate to the San Antonio Commandery of the Knights Templar, to Robert Eagan, 2 pp, 8vo, printed in red and black, with printed date of July 7, 1879. Folded, minor browning.
WITH: 3 clipped specimens of letterhead of the Daughters of the Republic of Texas, printed in black, red, brown and blue, bearing the printed name of Clara Driscoll as President and Treasurer of the Alamo Mission Fund Organization. Browning.

lot_info.sDesc: LAMBART, RICHARD. 1722-1778.  A New System of Military Discipline, Founded upon Principle. Philadelphia R. Aitkin, 1776.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
LAMBART, RICHARD. 1722-1778.
A New System of Military Discipline, Founded upon Principle. Philadelphia: R. Aitkin, 1776.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
LAMBART, RICHARD. 1722-1778.
A New System of Military Discipline, Founded upon Principle. Philadelphia: R. Aitkin, 1776.
8vo (190 x 112 mm). Rebacked contemporary sheep. Rubbed, corners repaired, dampstaining to bottom outside corner through first 2 gatherings, browning and spotting.

FIRST EDITION. Lambart (sometimes spelled "Lambert") was an Irishman with a long career in the British Army, reaching the rank of Lieutenant General, and holding his commission until the end of his life. Aitken printed his book, which includes an appendix full of "moral observations," as a manual for militia officers. It was used as an instructional textbook by both sides during the Revolutionary War. Evans 14815; Sabin 53405.

next_lot.desc: LINCOLN'S 1861 INAUGURATION. [LINCOLN, ABRAHAM. 1809-1865.] A piece of fine floral silk from the dress worn by Abraham Lincoln's niece Elizabeth Edwards Clover to his 1861 Inaugural Ball, March 4th, 1861,

lot_info.sDesc: LINCOLN'S 1861 INAUGURATION. LINCOLN, ABRAHAM. 1809-1865. A piece of fine floral silk from the dress worn by Abraham Lincoln's niece Elizabeth Edwards Clover to his 1861 Inaugural Ball, March 4th, 1861,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
LINCOLN'S 1861 INAUGURATION.
[LINCOLN, ABRAHAM. 1809-1865.]
A piece of fine floral silk from the dress worn by Abraham Lincoln's niece Elizabeth Edwards Clover to his 1861 Inaugural Ball, March 4th, 1861,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
LINCOLN'S 1861 INAUGURATION.
[LINCOLN, ABRAHAM. 1809-1865.] A piece of fine floral silk from the dress worn by Abraham Lincoln's niece Elizabeth Edwards Clover to his 1861 Inaugural Ball, March 4th, 1861, a 9 x 8 x 5 inch triangle, colored silk striped in green, black, and gray, with floral design in rose, green and blue, some staining, old stitches.
Provenance: Elizabeth Edwards Clover (1843-1910), niece of President and Mrs. Lincoln; Mary Edwards Brown, by descent; sold to Dorothy Meserve Kunhardt (1901-1979), Lincoln historian and collector (signed and notarized letter of acquisition dated 1957).

A BEAUTIFUL FAMILY MEMENTO OF LINCOLN'S INAUGURAL BALL. According to Michael Burlingame, Elizabeth Edwards Clover "inherited much of her famous aunt's wardrobe, which she regularly wore even though the large silk skirts, lace shawls, and tiny carriage parasols had long since passed out of style" (Life, p 181).

next_lot.desc: MAPPING NORTH AMERICA. A collection of 19 18th- and 19th-century maps of North America, including:

lot_info.sDesc: MAPPING NORTH AMERICA. A collection of 19 18th- and 19th-century maps of North America, including
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
MAPPING NORTH AMERICA.
A collection of 19 18th- and 19th-century maps of North America, including:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
MAPPING NORTH AMERICA.
A collection of 19 18th- and 19th-century maps of North America, including:
1. VANDERMAELEN, PHILLIPPE MARIE GUILLAUME. 1795-1869.
Ten hand-colored lithographed maps of the United States (sheets 21,45,50-53, 55-57bis, 61), from Vandermaelen's Atlas Universelle, [Brussels: 1827], various sizes, versos blank. Some light staining to a few margins. The first attempt at a map of the world published on a uniform scale. In this group are maps of New England and the eastern seaboard, Ohio and Kentucky, Kansas and parts of Southern California.
2. BELLIN, JACQUES NICOLAS. 1703-1772.
Carte Reduite du Golphe de St. Laurent. Paris: 1754. Engraved map of the Gulf of the St Lawrence, 550 x 870 mm, verso blank. Titled at upper right, window mount. Kershaw 586.
Carte du cours du fleuve de Saint Laurent....1761, sheets I and II, each 580 x 870 mm. Very lightly browned to extremities;
3. JEFFERYS, THOMAS. 1719-1771.
An exact Chart of the River St Laurence. London: 1775, hand-colored in outline on two sheets joined, lightly discolored; WITH: Plan of the Town and Fortifications of Montreal. London: 1758 [but 1760], window mount. Howes J-83; Sabin 35964;
AND WITH: Tirions's Quebek, de Hoofstad ven Kanada: ann de Rivier van St Laurens. [1769], hand-colored in outline, window mount. Kershaw 1018; two other plans of Quebec, and Wyld's military map on Montreal and surroundings.

next_lot.desc: MARINE CORPS ARCHIVE. Archive of material related to World War II Marine Corps veteran,

lot_symbols.sLongDesc: Lot to be sold without reserve.

lot_info.sDesc: MARINE CORPS ARCHIVE. Archive of material related to World War II Marine Corps veteran,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
MARINE CORPS ARCHIVE.
Archive of material related to World War II Marine Corps veteran,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
MARINE CORPS ARCHIVE.
Archive of material related to World War II Marine Corps veteran, Platoon Sargeant Bertrand S. Esler, Jr., including: 8 x 10 inch photographs, including color portrait photograph in dress uniform, portrait of Esler holding his Purple Heart medal, group photo of Esler's platoon. * Approximately 80 loose photographs, contained in modern vinyl album sleeves and 3-ring binder, most around 4.5 x 3.5 inches, depicting Marines in training, landing supplies on a beach, shots taken on the Marshall Islands, including some risque' photos of local women, post-battle photos of dead Japanese soldiers, and five calling card photos of Japanese soldiers. * Assignment letter dated March 31, 1939. * Thanksgiving dinner menu of the 6h Marines at San Diego, November 21, 1940. * A wartime photograph album with painted leather cover, containing approximately 135 photographs taken during training at various locations in California. *
"Ancient Order of the Deep" document dated July 10, 1942, issued on board U.S.S. President Jackson. * Autograph letters from Esler to his mother. * Honorable Discharge documents dated March 31, 1938 and September 15, 1945. * A typed copy of the authorization letter for awarding the Purple Heart to Esler for action at Guadalcanal, dated January 23, 1943. * A letter to Esler's parents dated March 17, 1945, informing them that their son had been wounded in the leg at Iwo Jima on the 24th of February that year. * Applications and for disability compensation and other documents related to gunshot wounds through his upper right arm and lower left leg, various dates through 1949.
WITH: Photograph album belonging to Private First Class John M. Rhude, USMC, with decorated suede cover, containing approximately 125 photos in various sizes, depicting group members of his unit, fellow marines in baseball garb, post-battle photos of Iwo Jima including structures, crashed and captured airplanes, an anti-aircraft gun, bodies of Japanese soldiers, tanks, and landing craft, and other subjects.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
MARSHALL, JOHN. 1755-1835.

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
MARSHALL, JOHN. 1755-1835.
The Life of George Washington.... Philadelphia: C.P. Wayne, 1804.
5 volumes. 8vo (218 x 130 mm). Engraved frontis in volume 1. Contemporary tree calf, spine gilt, with red and black titling pieces. Joints starting slightly, spotting, offset, light shelfwear.
WITH: The Life of George Washington: Maps and Subscriber's Names. Philadelphia: C.P. Wayne, 1807. 4to (285 x 230 mm). With 10 engraved maps, 9 folding, and 22 pp list of subscribers. Half calf over marbled boards. Light spotting and toning.

FIRST EDITION, FIRST ISSUE, OF THE FIRST BIOGRAPHY OF WASHINGTON, WITH ATLAS AND SUBSCRIBER LIST. The first three volumes are dated 1804; there was a second issue between 1805-1807. Howes M317 aa; Sabin 44788.

American League baseball featuring signatures of NICK ETTEN, FRANK BOROWY, MIKE MILOSEVICH, STEVE ROSER, MIKE GARBARK, JOHN LINDELL, BOB COLLINS, MEL QUEEN, GEORGE STERNWEISS, OSCAR GRIMES, FRANK CROSSETTI, JOHNNY JOHNSON, WALT DUBIEL, PAUL SCHREIBER,

lot_info.sDesc: NEW YORK YANKEES 1944 TEAM-SIGNED BASEBALL. American League baseball featuring signatures of NICK ETTEN, FRANK BOROWY, MIKE MILOSEVICH, STEVE ROSER, MIKE GARBARK, JOHN LINDELL, BOB COLLINS, MEL QUEEN, GEORGE STERNWEISS, OSCAR GRIMES, FRANK CROSSETTI, JOHNNY JOHNSON, WALT DUBIEL, PAUL SCHREIBER,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
NEW YORK YANKEES 1944 TEAM-SIGNED BASEBALL.
American League baseball featuring signatures of NICK ETTEN, FRANK BOROWY, MIKE MILOSEVICH, STEVE ROSER, MIKE GARBARK, JOHN LINDELL, BOB COLLINS, MEL QUEEN, GEORGE STERNWEISS, OSCAR GRIMES, FRANK CROSSETTI, JOHNNY JOHNSON, WALT DUBIEL, PAUL SCHREIBER,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
NEW YORK YANKEES 1944 TEAM-SIGNED BASEBALL.
American League baseball featuring signatures of NICK ETTEN, FRANK BOROWY, MIKE MILOSEVICH, STEVE ROSER, MIKE GARBARK, JOHN LINDELL, BOB COLLINS, MEL QUEEN, GEORGE STERNWEISS, OSCAR GRIMES, FRANK CROSSETTI, JOHNNY JOHNSON, WALT DUBIEL, PAUL SCHREIBER, BUD METHENY, ARTHUR FLETCHER, RUSS DERRY, TUCK STAINBACK , BILL ZUBER, JOHNNY NEUN[?], HIRSCH MARTIN, ATLEY DONALD, DON SAVAGE, JIM TURNER, ERNIE BONHAM, and J. SCHULTE, varnish darkened and some wear overall.

In spite of losing some of their best players to the war effort (Joe Dimaggio, Phil Rizzuto), the Yankees still fielded exceptional teams during World War II. They made it to the World Series in 1942, losing to the St. Louis Cardinals, and were rematched in 1943, taking the championship in five games. In 1944 they ended up third in the American League.

next_lot.desc: NIXON AND WATERGATE. Archive of Nixon and Watergate related correspondence and ephemera,

lot_info.sDesc: NIXON AND WATERGATE. Archive of Nixon and Watergate related correspondence and ephemera,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
NIXON AND WATERGATE.
Archive of Nixon and Watergate related correspondence and ephemera,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
NIXON AND WATERGATE.
Archive of Nixon and Watergate related correspondence and ephemera, including: Typed Note Signed, being a copy of his resignation letter to Kissinger, on White House watermarked letterhead. * Another, facsimile copy of the original. * Typed Letter Signed, 1 p, to a Mrs. Sutherland, April 29, 1946, on letterhead of Bewley, Knoop & Nixon, thanking her for help in supporting his campaign for Congress. * Typed Letter Signed, 1 p, to Mrs. Sutherland (as above), November 7, 1980, on personal letterhead, stating that a signed photograph was enclosed. * Official inauguration program for Nixon's first inauguration, January 20, 1969, in printed wrappers. * Admission ticket to grandstands for the 2nd inauguration, January 20, 1973. * Official engraved invitation to the first inauguration of Nixon, January 20, 1969. * Another, to second inauguration, January 20, 1973. * Thank-you card with Christmas and New Years wishes from Nixon as President Elect, 1968, with family photo and facsimile signature. * Official engraved admission card to the inauguration ceremonies for the second inauguration, January 20, 1973. * Inauguration ceremonies program for the second inauguration. * Bureau of Engraving and Printing portrait of Nixon on card. * Inauguration day first-day cover, 1969, with four 3-cent stamps, SIGNED by Nixon. * Another, with 6-cent stamp, unsigned. * 8 x 10 color photograph of President and Mrs. Nixon, standing, inscribed and signed by both Pat and Richard Nixon. * Black and white portrait photograph with facsimile signature. * Black and white portrait photograph of Spiro Agnew, with facsimile signature. * Three printed letters with facsimile signatures, to supporters, dated 1951, 1952 and 1953. * Gerald Ford signed card with printed copy of his act pardoning Nixon, dated 11/5/79. * Typed Letter Signed from Gerald Ford as Vice President, June 19, 1974. * Statement on America's Bicentennial, signed by Ford, on White House letterhead, May 21, 1976. * A series of signed notes, photographs, and letters from people involved in the Watergate break-in and subsequent trial, including Ron Ziegler, E. Howard Hunt, John Ehrlichman, H.R. Haldeman, Leon Jaworski, Sam Ervin, G. Gordon Liddy, Dwight Chapin, Rose Mary Woods, Archibald Cox, Lowell Weicker, and Judge John Sirica.
Contained in a zippered black leather binder. Condition varies, generally fine.

next_lot.desc: PICKENS, FRANCIS WILKINSON. 1805-1869. Autograph Letter Signed ("F.W. Wilkinson"), to Colonel John B.E. Sloan regarding troop movements,

lot_info.sDesc: PICKENS, FRANCIS WILKINSON. 1805-1869. Autograph Letter Signed (F.W. Wilkinson), to Colonel John B.E. Sloan regarding troop movements,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
PICKENS, FRANCIS WILKINSON. 1805-1869.
Autograph Letter Signed ("F.W. Wilkinson"), to Colonel John B.E. Sloan regarding troop movements,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
PICKENS, FRANCIS WILKINSON. 1805-1869.
Autograph Letter Signed ("F.W. Wilkinson"), to Colonel John B.E. Sloan regarding troop movements, 1 p, 4to, "Head Quarters," May[?] 2, 1861, on lined paper, light toning and creasing, docketed on the verso.

Pickens was the Governor of South Carolina at the outset of the Civil War, when South Carolina was the first to secede from the Union. As such he authorized the first attack on Union troops during the Fort Sumpter crisis. In this letter, written during the run up to First Manassas, Pickens orders Colonel John Sloan, leader of the 4th South Carolina Infantry, to move his troops to Richmond. In part: "After being mustered in you are ordered to report yourself & Regt. as soon as possible to President Davis or the Genl. in command at Richmond. / 2nd. Capt [?]'s Company was attached to Col. Kershaw's regt. upon the condition that they should be allowed if they desired it, to join your Regt, if marched to Virginia...."

next_lot.desc: REVOLUTIONARY CONNECTICUT. A collection of approximately 50 documents, including manuscript receipts, pay orders, promissory notes, and contracts, some printed and accomplished in manuscript, signed by various officials,

lot_info.sDesc: REVOLUTIONARY CONNECTICUT. A collection of approximately 50 documents, including manuscript receipts, pay orders, promissory notes, and contracts, some printed and accomplished in manuscript, signed by various officials,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
REVOLUTIONARY CONNECTICUT.
A collection of approximately 50 documents, including manuscript receipts, pay orders, promissory notes, and contracts, some printed and accomplished in manuscript, signed by various officials,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
REVOLUTIONARY CONNECTICUT.
A collection of approximately 50 documents, including manuscript receipts, pay orders, promissory notes, and contracts, some printed and accomplished in manuscript, signed by various officials, 1747-1820, many docketed on verso, condition varies, with most in very good condition, a few with significant tears.

An interesting assortment of colonial, revolutionary and federal period manuscript documents, mostly signed by officials of the State of Connecticut, including Oliver Wolcott, Jr. (the second Treasury Secretary of the United States, after Alexander Hamilton), Robert Yates, John Nicholas, Joshua Chandler, James Crompton, and others. Also includes two printed documents from the states of North Carolina and Tennessee, the latter dated 1846. A fascinating look at the economic minutiae of the colonies and early United States.

lot_info.sDesc: ROSS, ALEXANDER. 1783-1856. Adventures of the First Settlers on the Oregon or Columbia River. London Smith, Elder and Co., 1849.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
ROSS, ALEXANDER. 1783-1856.
Adventures of the First Settlers on the Oregon or Columbia River. London: Smith, Elder and Co., 1849.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AMERICANA
ROSS, ALEXANDER. 1783-1856.
Adventures of the First Settlers on the Oregon or Columbia River. London: Smith, Elder and Co., 1849.
8v0 (193 x 120 mm). Folding lithographed map. Early 20th century three-quarter red morocco and cloth, spine gilt with 5 raised bands, top edge gilt. Joints tender, map linen-backed, scattered spotting.
Provenance: William H. Claflin, Jr. (Boston businessman and archaeologist, 1893-1982, bookplate, with inscription dated 1922).

FIRST EDITION. Ross was a Scottish-born Canadian adventurer who was hired by the partners of the Pacific Fur Company, founded and primarily owned by John Jacob Astor, to explore the Columbia River and establish trading posts. Although promised a partnership if the company succeeded, Astor later broke that promise. Ross continued to explore the western territories of the United States with the North West Company and the Hudson's Bay Company. Graff 3576; Howes R-448; Sabin 73327; Wagner-Camp 172.

WITH: HOSSACK, DAVID. Memoir of DeWitt Clinton. New York: J. Seymour, 1829. Portrait frontispiece with facsimile inscription and signature. Contemporary quarter cloth and boards. Upper cover detached, soiled and stained, heavy foxing.

next_lot.desc: BAUM, L. FRANK. 1856-1919. A collection of seven books written outside the Oz series with eight later adaptations:

lot_info.sDesc: BAUM, L. FRANK. 1856-1919. A collection of seven books written outside the Oz series with eight later adaptations
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
BAUM, L. FRANK. 1856-1919.
A collection of seven books written outside the Oz series with eight later adaptations:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
BAUM, L. FRANK. 1856-1919.
A collection of seven books written outside the Oz series with eight later adaptations:
1. American Fairy Tales. Chicago and New York: George M. Hill Co., 1901. 8vo. Original decorated white cloth designed by R. F. Seymour. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed and soiled.
2. The Master Key. Indianapolis: Bowen-Merrill Co., [1901]. 8vo. Original gilt lettered dark green cloth with full-color pictorial label designed by F. Y. Cory. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed and edges soiled; contemporary inscription and rubber stamps on front endpapers.
3. [BANCROFT, LAURA.] Policeman Blue Jay. Chicago: Reilly & Britton Co., [1907]. Illustrated by Maginel Wright Enright. 8vo. Original cloth-backed decorated papered boards designed by M. W. Enright. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed and soiled; internal fingermarks.
4. Father Goose's Year Book. Chicago: Reilly & Britton Co., [1907]. Illustrated by Walter J[oseph] Enright. 8vo. Original green cloth with pictorial label designed by W. J. Enright. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed and spine faded; three entries (January 2 and 3 and February 9) humorously filled in by previous owner.
5. Little Wizard Stories of Oz. Chicago: Reilly & Britton Co., [1914]. Illustrated by John R[ea] Neill. 8vo. Original tan cloth with full-color pictorial label designed by J. R. Neill. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed and soiled; contemporary inscription on ownership leaf.
6. Sky Island. Chicago: Reilly & Britton Co., [1912]. Illustrated by John R. Neill. 8vo. Original red cloth with full-color pictorial label designed by J. R. Neill. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed and soiled; contemporary inscription on ownership leaf.
7. Collection of eight Junior Editions of the Oz Books. Chicago: Rand McNally & Co., 1939. Illustrated by John R. Neill. Comprising: The Land of Oz; The Road to Oz; The Emerald City of Oz; The Patchwork Girl of Oz; Rinkitink in Oz; The Lost Princess of Oz; Little Dorothy and Toto of Oz; and The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman of Oz. Each 12mo. Original decorated laminated boards. FIRST EDITIONS THUS. Covers rubbed with some loss to spines.
8. WEHR, JULIAN. The Wizard of Oz. Akron, Ohio: Saalfield Publishing Co., 1944. Small 4to. Original decorated spiral-bound red papered boards within publisher's decorated dust jacket. FIRST EDITION THUS. Minor wear and spoiling; spine of jacket rubbed with some loss.

Engraved print, single sheet only, 210 x 175 mm (to plate marks), from The Book of Job. Marked "Proof" at lower right. Foxing, especially to margins, browning at lower part of image in caption area. Matted and Framed; not examined out of frame.

An uncolored proof of the illustration captioned "Thy Sons & thy Daughters were eating and drinking Wine in their eldest Brothers house & behold there came a great wind from the Wilderness & smote upon the four faces of the house & it fell upon the young Men & they are Dead."

LITERATURE AND ART
DETMOLD, EDWARD. 1883-1957.
Pencil study for an illustration from The Arabian Nights. Pencil on paper, 215 x 350 mm, depicting a man leading an ox cart, with a citadel in the background. Signed in pencil at lower right margin. Heavy foxing. Framed and glazed; not examined out of frame.

Edward Detmold and his twin brother, Charles Maurice, rose rapidly to prominence with their illustrations for Pictures from Birdland (1899) and Kipling's The Jungle Book (1903). Their collaboration was cut tragically short by Maurice's suicide in 1908.

lot_info.sDesc: EARLY BOARD GAME. Le Jeu Universel de l'Industrie Humaine. Paris Paul André Basset, 1814.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
EARLY BOARD GAME.
Le Jeu Universel de l'Industrie Humaine. [Paris: Paul André Basset, 1814.]
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
EARLY BOARD GAME.
Le Jeu Universel de l'Industrie Humaine. [Paris: Paul André Basset, 1814.]
Engraved and letterpress game board on two sheets joined at the center, 462 x 610 mm overall. A few small tears to edges, ink stains, fold creases, rolled.

An early humorous board game designed to be played with a pair of dice and some markers, in which players advance around a numerical sequence of 63 boxes, facing pitfalls that will prevent them from reaching the final box. The boxes that allow players to advance represent trades, such as carpenters, stonemasons, sculptors, boatmen, tailors, teachers, scientists, and finally typesetters and engravers. Basset printed wallpaper and various other saleable printed items at his shop on Rue Saint Jacques in Paris, and is known to have published games from 1793 until his retirement in 1819. His family continued the business until the 1860s. D'Allemagne Le noble jeu de l'oie en France, de 1640 à 1950 p 224.

1. CLARKE, HARRY. Tales of Mystery and Imagination. By Edgar Allan Poe. New York: Tudor Publishing Co., 1933. 4to. 32 tipped-in color plates. Original gilt lettered black cloth with pictorial label designed by E. Dulac. FIRST AMERICAN EDITION THUS. Covers rubbed.
2. DETMOLD, EDWARD JULIUS and CHARLES MAURICE. Pictures from Birdland. London and New York, [1899]. 24 chromolithographs. 8vo. Original decorated light gray pictorial boards designed by E. J. Detmold. FIRST EDITION. Covers rubbed, front hinge starting; some internal soiling.
3. DETMOLD, EDWARD JULIUS. The Book of Baby Birds. New York, [1912]. 8vo. Original silver decorated cloth-backed blue boards with full color label designed by E. J. Detmold. FIRST EDITION. Edges rubbed, some internal soiling; contemporary inscription on front free endpaper.
4. DULAC, EDMUND. The Dreamer of Dreams. By the Queen of Roumania. London, New York, Toronto, [1915]. 4to. Original gilt lettered decorated gray cloth designed by E. Dulac. FIRST EDITION. Edges foxed; first and final page toned.
5. DULAC, EDMUND. Treasure Island. New York, [1927]. 4to. Original gilt lettered green cloth. FIRST AMERICAN EDITION THUS. Minor wear.
6. MACKENZIE, THOMAS. The Crock of Gold. London, 1926. 12 tipped-in color plates. 4to. Original half-vellum within publisher's dust jacket. FIRST EDITION THUS. One of 525 signed copies on hand made paper. Some toning of endpapers; jacket split with some loss.

lot_info.sDesc: JOHNSON, CHARLES. (PSEUD.)  A General History of the Pyrates.... London T. Woodward, 1726-28.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
JOHNSON, CHARLES. (PSEUD.)
A General History of the Pyrates.... London: T. Woodward, 1726-[28].
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
JOHNSON, CHARLES. (PSEUD.)
A General History of the Pyrates.... London: T. Woodward, 1726-[28].
2 volumes. 8vo (197 x 123 mm). 3 engraved plates (1 folding). Contemporary half calf and marbled boards, spines gilt with 5 raised bands. Covers detached, foxing, toning to page edges, corner of F6 in volume I and G4 in volume II torn, affecting some text.

Fourth edition. This work is often attributed to Daniel Defoe, though the work has recently been linked to Nathaniel Mist, a former sailor, journalist, and publisher of the Weekly Journal. First published in 1724, it was influential in forming the mythology of pirates, referencing for the first time pirates with missing legs or eyes, buried treasure, and the term "Jolly Roger." See J. R. Moore. "Defoe in the pillory," 1939, pp 126-188, and P.N. Furbank and W.R. Owens "Defoe de-attributions," 1994, pp 133-134. Sabin 36190.

LITERATURE AND ART
KEITH, DORA WHEELER. 1856-1940.
Archive of original artwork and family memorabilia, including:
1. Album of illustrations by Dora Wheeler Keith, containing approximately 82 images, most charcoal drawings, a few in watercolors, most of them drafts or originals of illustration art, mounted on card stock (some loose), as well as some printed versions of her art in the form of Christmas cards and other imprints, bound in hand-stitched linen over boards, 360 x 300 mm, corners frayed, browning, chipping to some edges.
2. Painting of Dora Wheeler Keith by Rosina Emmet Sherwood, watercolor on paper, 515 x 352 mm (image size), matted and framed. Light yellowing to paper.
3. Sketchbook containing 32 pencil sketches, some laid down and others drawn directly on the sketchbook pages, not signed, some bearing dates ranging from 1860 to 1866, with 4 small clipped pencil sketches laid down to front paste-down, oblong 8vo (175 x 250 mm), bound in brown cloth. Rubbed at corners, some chipping to edges, browning.
4. 22 watercolor illustrations and sketches, some mounted on board, a few signed, dating from 1872 to 1929, various approximately 200 x 180 mm to 320 x 310 mm, most with staining, chipping to corners and edges, and browning.
5. A group of 6 letters (5 autograph and 1 typed), between various members of the family and associates of Dora Wheeler Kieth, dating between 1895 and 1912, including a letter on American Association for the Advancement of Science stationery from Leland O. Howard to Dora Wheeler Kieth regarding a search through records of the Society of Colonial Wars. Dates range from
6. 24 photographs of various family members, including some of Dora Wheeler Keith, many removed from a photo album, some bearing captions and dates, approximately 5 x 7 inches and smaller.
7. Group of 10 typed letters between Dr. Ila Weiss and H. Keith Simpson regarding the preparation of a book about Candace Wheeler. (H. Keith Simpson is the grandson of Candace Wheeler).
8. Miscellaneous clipped sketches in pencil and ink, printed illustrations by other artists, and some printed Christmas cards with illustrations by Keith.
9. WHEELER, CANDACE. Double Darling and the Dreamspinner. New York: Fox, Duffield and Co., 1905. 8vo. Chromolithographic illustrations by Dora Wheeler Keith. Publisher's blue cloth with pictorial panel applied to upper cover. Rubbed, slight browning.

Dora Wheeler was the daughter of Candace Thurber Wheeler, a prominent woman designer who championed the involvement of women in the arts. Dora and her family traveled extensively in the years after the Civil War; she was largely educated in Weisbaden, and spent summers in Montreux, sketching incessantly, as can be seen in many of the sketches included here. She studied under William Meritt Chase in New York, and was well established as an illustration artist prior to her marriage to lawyer Boudinot Keith. She was also a talented portraitist, and her works can be seen in museums including the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and the National Portrait Gallery in Washington DC.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
KENT, ROCKWELL. 1882-1971.
Collection of seven illustrated books:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
KENT, ROCKWELL. 1882-1971.
Collection of seven illustrated books:
1. MELVILLE, HERMAN. Moby Dick. New York: Random House, [1930]. 4to. Original silver decorated black cloth. Covers rubbed; some soiling; contemporary inscription on front free endpaper. FIRST TRADE EDITION.
2. Rockwellkentiana: Few Words and Many Pictures. New York: Harcourt, Brace and Co., 1933. 4to. Original decorated white cloth. Edges rubbed, some soiling.
3. Salamina. New York: Harcourt, Brace and Co., 1935. 8vo. Original silver stamped blue cloth within publisher's pictorial dust jacket. Covers rubbed; endpapers partially toned with contemporary inscriptions; front flap detached and small pieces missing from dust jacket.
4. This Is My Own. New York: Duell, Sloan and Pearce, [1940]. 8vo. Original embossed white cloth in publisher's pictorial dust jacket and prospectus laid in. Minor wear; contemporary bookplate. Signed by the author in ink on the half-title page: "Rockwell Kent."
5. SCHNITZLER, ARTHUR. Casanova's Homecoming. New York: Sylvan Press, 1947. 4to. Original two-color embossed papered boards within publisher's plastic jacket. No. 96 of 1499 large paper copies for the American public and designed by Lewis F. White. Minor wear; piece missing from back jacket.
6. It's Me O Lord. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co., [1955]. 8vo. Original gilt stamped black cloth. Edges rubbed.
7. Of Men and Mountains. Ausable Forks, N. Y.: Asgaard Press, 1959 [1958]. 8vo. Original cloth-backed marbled boards within publisher's glassine jacket. No. 102 of 150 signed copies, inscribed: "To Juliet and Frank: Merry Christmas! — (1958!) Rockwell Kent 1959." Minor wear.

LOBEL-RICHE, ALMERY. 1877-1950.
BENOIT, PIERRE. 1886-1962. L'Atlantide Edition definitive illustree ... par Lobel-Riche. Paris: Albin Michel, [1922].
4to. 330 x 255 mm. Etched frontispiece and 23 erotic plates and headpieces, this a special copy on velin d'arches, unnumbered or lettered, with the signed original pencil sketch signed by the artist, and a selection of loose plates comprising the frontispiece in 2 states, an extra suite of 24 etched plates, printed in colors. Original printed wrappers, in glassine, the glassine chipped at head and foot of spine.

A fine hors de commerce copy, this a presentation copy to Lobel-Riche's sister Mathilde, signed by Lobel-Riche but inscribed and dated 22 December 1922 in another hand on the limitation leaf.

LOBEL-RICHE, ALMÉRY. 1877-1950.
VERLAINE, PAUL. 1844-1896.
Parallèlement. Paris: Paul Haasen, [1943].
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
LOBEL-RICHE, ALMÉRY. 1877-1950.
VERLAINE, PAUL. 1844-1896. Parallèlement. Paris: Paul Haasen, [1943].
4to (320 x 245 mm). Original copper plate, original signed drawing, two additional suites of plates, extra-illustrated with 50 original drawings. Modern burgundy morocco by Gruel, blind-ruled and gilt decorations on covers in Art Deco style, upper cover mounted with inset original copper plate, gilt turn-ins, red watered silk doublures and endleaves, edges gilt, marbled paper slipcase. Wear to slipcase, upper joint starting.
Provenance: RB/BR (unidentified booklabel).

DELUXE EDITION, number 1 of 10 copies in this state, with a double suite of plates, one on Japan and one on Arches vellum, and an original copper plate, mounted here with 50 ORIGINAL SKETCHES bound at the back. First published in 1889, Parallèlement was conceived by Verlaine as a compilation of poetic works on the topics of Wisdom, Love and Happiness. They explore various aspects of sexuality, illustrated in this edition by Lobel-Riche's rich imagery.

Unpublished illustration The Wonder City of Oz (1940).

The Hungry Tiger first appeared in L. Frank Baum's Ozma of Oz (1907) and quickly became one of the most beloved of Oz characters. He looks uncharacteristically fierce here.

ORWELL, GEORGE. 1903-1950.
Typed Letter Signed ("Geo. Orwell") to Edward R. Ward on his right to express his opinions on science,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
ORWELL, GEORGE. 1903-1950.
Typed Letter Signed ("Geo. Orwell") to Edward R. Ward on his right to express his opinions on science, 1 p, London, January 9, 1946, folds, tape remnants in 3 places at margin.

ORWELL ON SCIENCE. As part of a continuing exchange of letters with scientist Edward R. Ward, Orwell asserts again the layman's right to engage with science. Mr. Ward had responded to Orwell's "What is Science" in the Tribune in October 1945, but the Tribune printed only an abridged version of his letter. Orwell had responded in print again in November, but without the full text of Ward's original letter. This January 9, 1946, letter is his private response to the letter in full. See Orwell, Collected Works, Volume 19: I Belong to the Left, 1945, pp 327-8.

LITERATURE AND ART
PRICE, KEN. 1935-2012.
BUKOWSKI, CHARLES. 1920-1994. Heat Wave. Santa Rosa: Black Sparrow Graphic Arts, 1995.
Folio. Illustrated in text, 15 additional color serigraphs by Ken Price (4 are signed), laid in loose in portfolio at end, as issued, and compact disc recoding of Bukowski reading his poetry inserted in pocket on front paste-down. Publisher's pictorial cloth, Plexiglas slipcase. Slipcase edges separating, soiling to top and bottom edges of slipcase, light marginal dampstaining on binding, not affecting interior.
Provenance: Thomas Lundstrom (d.1999, Partner in Black Sparrow Graphic Arts); gift to the present owner, 1999.

DELUXE EDITION, THE COMPLETE PORTFOLIO COMPRISING 15 SCREENPRINTS IN COLOR,number 48 of 170 copies plus 26 lettered copies. Signed by the artist in the colophon; 4 of the prints are numbered "48/170" and signed. Bukowski's 31 blunt but sympathetic poems about life in Los Angeles are accompanied by Price's illustrations of the gritty, sometimes squalid hard-edged city translated into vibrant areas of color.

Part of the proceeds of the sale of this item will be donated to the SEED school for disadvantaged inner city youth in the memory of Thomas Lundstrom.

The Algerine Captive; or, the Life and Adventures of Doctor Updike Underhill: Six Years a Prisoner .... Walpole, NH: 1797.
2 volumes. 12mo (158 x 98 mm). Modern gilt-ruled morocco, signed Bennett, N.Y. on front turn-in. Browning, slight chipping to first title page, a few inked margin notes.

FIRST EDITION, published anonymously by Boston playwright and jurist Royall Tyler. Tyler gained fame with his play The Contract, the first American-written and performed play, which debuted in New York City in the same year this work was published, and was attended by then-President George Washington. Rare, with only two other copies known at auction since 1945. Evans 3295.

Interpretations of Poetry and Religion. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1900.
8vo. Modern red quarter morocco and cloth, gilt titles on spine. Toning and slight soiling, small tear to free front endpaper.
Provenance: Learned Hand (inscription on free front endpaper).

LEARNED HAND'S COPY ownership signature and extensive penciled notes throughout, including some erasures and corrections. At the end of the text, Hand has written an extensive note that continues across recto and verso of two blank leaves. Learned Hand (1872-1961) served as judge on the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York and later the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. He was known for the clarity of his legal writings, and his judicial philosophy.

LITERATURE AND ART
SHAKESPEARE, WILLIAM. 1564-1616.
Works of Shakespeare edited by W.E. Henley. Edinburgh and New York: T. and A. Constable, [1903].
18 volumes only (of 20). Small folio. Extra-illustrated with original pen, ink and watercolors by H.C. Green and others, water-color and gilt illumination in the Art Nouveau manner throughout, and various hand-colored and black and white engravings. Contemporary dark green morocco by R. Jackel and Co. NY, elaborately gilt, covers with foliate design, incorporating white and red onlays around the central arms. Spine in six compartments, gilt inner dentelles, silk doublures and endleaves, top edges gilt. Spines slightly sunned, some offsetting from plates.

A very fine set of the LIMITED "ANNE HATHAWAY EDITION" OF THE EXTRA ILLUSTRATED HENLEY SHAKESPEARE, this number 11 of 50 copies, with elaborate Art Nouveau decoration to borders and head and tail pieces, in addition to c.120 colored and plain engravings and watercolors of Shakespearean characters by H.C Green and others.

LITERATURE AND ART
SHAKESPEARE, WILLIAM. 1564-1616.
DRYDEN, JOHN, editor. 1631-1700. Troilus and Cressida; or, truth found too late. A tragedy as it is acted at the Dukes Theatre. London: for Abel Swall and Jacob Tonson, 1679.
4to (215 x 159 mm). Modern blue morocco. Some soiling and staining, cropped early marginalia, tape repairs on verso of title, minor marginal restoration on several other leaves. Late 19th-century blue morocco gilt, gilt edges.
Provenance: some marginal annotations to the preface in a contemporary hand (cropped by the binder); inscription along outer margin of I2v; "Mancher September 17 1821" (inscription along outer margin of I3r); William Foyle (bookplate, his sale Christie's London, 11 July 2000, part of lot 464).

FIRST EDITION of Dryden's adaptation of Shakespeare's play. It was first performed at Dorset Garden in the spring of 1679 with "The Prologue Spoken by Mr. Betterton Representing the Ghost of Shakespear." Betterton played Troilus and his wife, Andromache. Shakespeare's original text was first printed in 1609. Bartlett 164; Jaggard p 476; MacDonald 84a; Pforzheimer 915; Wing D-2388; ESTC R16367.

lot_info.sDesc: TURGENEV, IVAN. 1818-1883.  Autograph Letter Signed (Ivan Tougneneff), in English, to Charles Scribner, 2 pp, 8vo (200 x 125 mm), Paris, September 16, 1881,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
TURGENEV, IVAN. 1818-1883.
Autograph Letter Signed ("Ivan Tougneneff"), in English, to Charles Scribner, 2 pp, 8vo (200 x 125 mm), Paris, September 16, 1881,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
LITERATURE AND ART
TURGENEV, IVAN. 1818-1883.
Autograph Letter Signed ("Ivan Tougneneff"), in English, to Charles Scribner, 2 pp, 8vo (200 x 125 mm), Paris, September 16, 1881, matted and mounted in double-sided framed to 280 x 200 mm.

To Mr. Scribner, editor of Scribner's Monthly, Turgenev sends a polite refusal to a solicitation of work to be published in the magazine. In part: "I never mean anything but a novel or a tale. Political articles are not in my line—and I could not at all fulfill the programme you propose me. It would be rather difficult for me to write even a novel now—as I have almost given up writing. However—I am willing to try and if I can draw anything from my exhausted stock, you will certainly have 'the primear' of it. But I can not engage me to any date— or give a title beforehand."

Turgenev writes to a good friend who has given him a draft of a work titled "La Fiancee de Mozart" to read, and the writer does not have much good to say about it, mostly because he feels that Pushkin's drama, Mozart and Salieri, is so excellent that there is no room for another literary take.

next_lot.desc: DEATH OF THE MARQUIS DE CINQ-MARS. 5 illustrations depicting the death of Cinq-Mars,

lot_info.sDesc: DEATH OF THE MARQUIS DE CINQ-MARS. 5 illustrations depicting the death of Cinq-Mars,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
DEATH OF THE MARQUIS DE CINQ-MARS.
5 illustrations depicting the death of Cinq-Mars,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
WORLD HISTORY AND TRAVEL LITERATURE
DEATH OF THE MARQUIS DE CINQ-MARS.
5 illustrations depicting the death of Cinq-Mars, hand-colored engraved prints, by J.P.M. Jazet after Hippolyte Lecomte, each 500 x 620 mm, with engraved captions at bottom margins. Titles include "Cinq-Mars présenté au Roi," "Cinq Mars et Marie a la Chasse Royale," "Duel de Cinq-Mars," "Cinq-Mars et de Thou prisonniers de Richelieu," and "Cinq-Mars et de Thou marchant au Supplice." Heavy foxing, toning. Framed and glazed; not examined out of frame.

A series depicting the life and death of Henri Coiffier de Ruzé, Marquis of Cinq-Mars (1620-1642), who was introduced to the court of Louis XIII by Cardinal Richelieu, only to fall out of favor with the powerful Cardinal. Cinq-Mars tried to convince the King to have Richelieu executed, but his own plots gave the Cardinal a justification for having him executed.

next_lot.desc: FRIEDEL, ADAM DE. 1780-? [The Greeks. Twenty Four portraits of the principal leaders and personages ... in the Greek Revolution.] London: Adam de Friedel, 1827.

lot_info.sDesc: FRIEDEL, ADAM DE. 1780- The Greeks. Twenty Four portraits of the principal leaders and personages ... in the Greek Revolution. London Adam de Friedel, 1827.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
FRIEDEL, ADAM DE. 1780-?
[The Greeks. Twenty Four portraits of the principal leaders and personages ... in the Greek Revolution.] London: Adam de Friedel, 1827.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
WORLD HISTORY AND TRAVEL LITERATURE
FRIEDEL, ADAM DE. 1780-?
[The Greeks. Twenty Four portraits of the principal leaders and personages ... in the Greek Revolution.] London: Adam de Friedel, 1827.
9 loose plates. Folio (486 x 350 mm). Hand-colored lithographic plates from Friedel's series, including portraits of Odysseus Tritzo, Johannes Mavromichaelis, Photius Carapano, Nikytas, Chourchid Pasha, Prince Demitrios Ypsilantis, Ali Bey, Madon, and Constantine Canaris. All with some browning and handling wear, 3 plates (Chourchid, Nikytas and Ypsilantis) with dampstaining to corners, Mavromichaelis heavily browned, Canaris with tears to right margin.

Friedel, a Dane, was a veteran of the Napoleonic Wars who later traveled in the Ottoman Empire and Russia, and joined the Greek forces during the War of Independence. He assumed the title of Baron Friedel von Friedelsburg, but his false claims of aristocratic lineage led him to be expelled from the Greek Army. He opened a lithography shop in London, where he published a collection of lithographs from his drawings, prepared and colored by Jules Bouvier (1800-1867). Blackmer 633.

lot_info.sDesc: MARKOVITCH, EMILE. 1894-1981. Group of photographs of European Royalty and other personalities.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
MARKOVITCH, EMILE. 1894-1981.
Group of photographs of European Royalty and other personalities.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
WORLD HISTORY AND TRAVEL LITERATURE
MARKOVITCH, EMILE. 1894-1981.
Group of photographs of European Royalty and other personalities. Gelatin silver prints, most printed with filters and signed in pencil, some captioned, various image sizes, 300 x 240 mm and smaller. Included portrait subjects are Prince Louis of Monaco, Princess Charlotte of Monaco, Princess Marina of Greece (3 images), Pierre de Fouquières (signed), Edouard Herriot, Anatole de Monzie (2 images, one inscribed), an image of the Moulin de Galette, smaller images of a young Prince Phillip of Greece (2), the Duchess of Kent (2), a series of press photos of a U.N. summit in Caracas, and others.

Marcovitch recorded many of the personalities of the Russian émigré community in Paris in the 1930s, including the Romanovs, as well as artists such as American transplant Sergei Rachmaninoff. Many of his portraits are printed with filters that give the impression of being charcoal drawings.

MAXIMILIAN I, EMPEROR OF MEXICO. 1832-1867.
Autograph Letter Signed, 1p ("Maximiliano"), to Minister of State Cortez Esparza, 2p recto and verso, 4to, Chapultepec Castle, July 28, 1866, expressing his confidence that the current political problems would resolve themselves in time. Light soiling, creases.
MOUNTED WITH: ITURBIDE, AUGUSTIN. 1783-1824. Autograph Letter Signed ("Augustin de Iturbide"), to an unknown recipient, 1p, 8vo, Hacienda del Colorado, March 20, 1821. Laid down. Fold creases, browning.
Both framed and glazed.

Maximilian writes to one of his ministers, expressing an optimism that proved unfounded. When his cabinet was later faced with a vote on whether he should abdicate, Cortez Esparza was the only minister who was unreservedly in support of abdication.

next_lot.desc: A MEDDO STICK CHART. [Marshall Islands?]: first half of 20th century.

lot_info.sDesc: A MEDDO STICK CHART. Marshall Islands first half of 20th century.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
A MEDDO STICK CHART.
[Marshall Islands?]: first half of 20th century.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
WORLD HISTORY AND TRAVEL LITERATURE
A MEDDO STICK CHART.
[Marshall Islands?]: first half of 20th century. A Marshall Islands or Polynesian stick chart, 350 x 330 mm, made up of a square of 4 sticks framing 21 smaller straight sticks, running in different directions, each direction denoting a form of ocean swells, the sticks bound at their main intersections with coconut sennit, and further decorated with 29 small cowrie shells attached to the wooden lattice, each shell representing an island, with two curved smaller wooden pieces curving around an island at lower center, representing the movement of the swell around that island in that locale.

A RARE EXAMPLE OF A STICK CHART. The existence of these stick charts and their use in navigation by native islanders canoeing around the multitude of islands in the central pacific only came to light in 1862 when a missionary in the Marshall Islands reported on their use. The structure and use of these ancient charts were only fully described by a Captain Winkler of the German Navy in the 1890s, whilst he was stationed in the Marshall Islands, which was at that time under German control. The use of stick charts died out after World War 2, but they had been in use for many centuries. An experienced native navigator would build up his knowledge of the four major swells of the Pacific Ocean, the rilib, kaelib, bungdockerik, and bunddockeing, and the charts concentrated on the effects of the islands blocking a swell, and creating counter swells, allowing a native navigator to use the swells to travel from island to island. The information in the chart was memorized and passed down from father to son. This example appears to have been constructed after 1900, as the wooden pieces are too finely cut, and there are remarkably few curved sticks denoting currents affected by islands — more of use for local navigation amongst a small chain of islands. It was acquired by a wreck hunter in the mid 20th century.

US$3,000-5,000

Tabula novarum insularum, quas diversis respectibus occidentales & indianas uocant. Basel: c.1550.

WORLD HISTORY AND TRAVEL LITERATURE
MUENSTER, SEBASTIAN. 1488-1552.
Tabula novarum insularum, quas diversis respectibus occidentales & indianas uocant. Basel: c.1550. Hand-colored woodcut map, 255 x 335 mm. Foxing, fold creases, some fading. Matted and framed; not examined out of frame.

An early printing of the Latin-titled version of Meunster's map, the first to depict both North and South America (among other firsts). It was later issued in a German-titled version in Muenster's Cosmography, published from 1540 to 1578. Burden 12.

SPANISH INQUISITION: ILLUMINATED MANUSCRIPT.
Illuminated Manuscript Signed conferring the title of comisario de la Inquisicion on Francisco de Luque Granados of Montemayor,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
WORLD HISTORY AND TRAVEL LITERATURE
SPANISH INQUISITION: ILLUMINATED MANUSCRIPT.
Illuminated Manuscript Signed conferring the title of comisario de la Inquisicion on Francisco de Luque Granados of Montemayor, 1 p, 306 x 602 mm, Cordoba, October 29, 1712, in italic hand in black ink with authorizing signatures in gold, the text set within three-sided painted border in colors and gold incorporating foliate decoration, vignette of St. Peter Martyr (Peter of Verona) with book, quill, and knife embedded in his head, and two-line heading interlaced within elaborate strapwork. Worn paper seal of the Inquisition in lower left, some soiling and creasing overall.

A handsome example of an appointment for an Inquisition court commissioner. Comisarios were parish priests who played an important ancillary role in the legal system of the Holy Office by performing non-judicial tasks on behalf of inquisitors.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
BURLIUK, DAVID DAVIDOVICH. 1882-1967.

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVIST LITERATURE / A PRIVATE COLLECTION SOLD WITHOUT RESERVE
BURLIUK, DAVID DAVIDOVICH. 1882-1967.
Kitovras. No. 3 (October), 1924.
8vo. Photogravure and line illustrations. Publisher's white wrappers designed by Bobrisk. Wrappers detached, worn and soiled. With contributions by V. V. Mayakovsky, D. Burliuk and others.
WITH: Oshima. [New York]: Maria Nikiforovna Burliuk, 1927. Folio. Photogravure illustrations. Publisher's Futurist gray wrappers. Signed and inscribed in ink by D. Burliuk. Front wrapper and final page chipped
WITH: K 25-tiletino khudozhestvenno literaturnoi deyatelnosti stikhi (1898g-1923g) [Twenty-Five Years of Artistic and Literary Activity (1898-1923)]. New York: Russkii Golos, 1924. 8vo. Photogravure illustrations. Publisher's photomontage grey wrappers. Wrappers soiled, spine partially split.

Of Ukrainian Cossack and Belarusian stock, David Burliuk and his brother Vladimir stood at the very center of the Russian Avant-Garde. In fact, David has been called the Father of Russian Futurism. (Vladimir was killed in World War I while fighting in the Imperial Army.) The elder Burliuk teamed up with Mayakovsky and Kamensky for scandalous Cubo-Futurist tours. They were constantly offending the authorities in their determination to deliver a good solid slap in the face of public taste. Burliuk fled Russia in 1918 and settled in the United States in 1922. He was not allowed to return to Mother Russia until 1965.

CHERNIKHOV, YAKOV GEORGIEVICH. 1889-1951.
Les Bases de l'architecture contemporaine. Leningrad: Édition de la Société des Architectes de Léningrad, 1930.
Folio. Illustrated with 225 photogravure and line illustrations. Publisher's two-color cloth-bathed Constructivist boards. Rebacked and edges rubbed.
WITH: Die Grundlagen der Modernen Architektur. Leningrad: Leningrader Architekten-Verein, 1931. Publisher's Constructivist boards. Rebacked and edges rubbed.

Controversial Soviet architect Y.G. Chernikhov, "the Soviet Piranesi," is more famous for what he did not build than for what he did build. His "architectural fantasies" in a series of splendid art books profoundly inspired many other architects and painters when his own homeland shunned him. He always considered himself more than just a Constructivist. He emerged as an important artistic force just as the Russian Avant-Garde was being challenged by Soviet Social Realism; his vibrant architectural drawings were denounced by the Party as Formalist and Counterrevolutionary.

3 titles, including:

Photomontage illustrations. Concrete poetry by A. Chicherin and Boris Zemenkov. Publisher's Constructivist white wrappers designed by Nikolai Nikolaevich Kupreyanov. Some wear with loss to spine. One of 1,500 copies.
2. GAN, ALEKSEI MIKHAILOVICH. 1887-1941; and BUDANTSEV, SERGEI FEDOROVICH. 1896-1938. Myatezh mobilizovannykh [Uprising of the Mobilized]. Moscow: Sovetskih Pisatelei, 1927. Square 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist white wrappers designed by A. Gan. Some wear, soiling.
3. LEF. Literatura fakta [The Literature of Facts]. Moscow: Federatsiya, 1929. 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist white boards. Edges rubbed.

Various publications embracing the Constructivist aesthetic in literature and graphic design. Literatura facta is an anthology with contributions by O. M. Brik, S. M. Tretyakov and other writers associated with LEF.

ESENIN, SERGEI ALEKSANDROVICH. 1895-1925; and ZDANEVICH, KIRILL MIKHAILOVICH. 1894-1975.
Strana sovetskaya [Soviet Country]. Tiflis: Sovesytkii Kavkaz, 1922.
8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by K. Zdanevich. Wrappers faded and soiled. MoMA 448.

While spending time in the Caucasus in 1924 and 1925, the famous peasant poet published most of the lyrics in this book in Baku and Tiflis daily newspapers. Strana Sovetskaya was among the last books published before the poet's suicide. He is perhaps best remembered in the West as one of Isadora Duncan's husbands. But in Russia he is even today one of his country's favorite poets.

GRIGORIEV, BORIS DMITRIEVICH. 1886-1939.
Intimité. Petersburg: V. M. Yasnyi, 1918.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVIST LITERATURE / A PRIVATE COLLECTION SOLD WITHOUT RESERVE
GRIGORIEV, BORIS DMITRIEVICH. 1886-1939.
Intimité. Petersburg: V. M. Yasnyi, 1918.
Folio. Tipped-in color frontispiece. Illustrated with black-and-white photogravures and line drawings. Essays by Vsevolod Dmitriev and Vsevolod Voinov. Publisher's two-color decorated wrappers. Some wear, bottom corner of front wrapper chipped.

A remarkably elegant exploration of the French demimonde, dedicated to the prostitutes who posed for the Russian émigré artist. After studying at the Imperial Academy of Arts in Saint Petersburg, Grigoriev joined the World of Art group of Benois and Diaghilev. While traveling abroad, he continued to work for those Russians living in exile in the West. He was as dexterous in his erotic drawings as in his charming illustrations for Sasha Chorny's Detskii ostrov [The Children's Island] (1921).

KLUTSIS, GUSTAV GUSTAVOVICH. 1895-1938; AND VALENTINA NIKIFOROVNA KULAGINA. 1902-1987.
4 works by the couple,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVIST LITERATURE / A PRIVATE COLLECTION SOLD WITHOUT RESERVE
KLUTSIS, GUSTAV GUSTAVOVICH. 1895-1938; AND VALENTINA NIKIFOROVNA KULAGINA. 1902-1987.
4 works by the couple, including:
1. KLUTSIS, GUSTAV GUSTAVOVICH. Izofront: Klassovaya borba na fronte prostranstvennykh iskusstv [Art Front: Class Struggle on the Visual Arts Front]. Moscow and Leningrad: OGIZ Izogiz, 1931. Square 8vo. Photogravure illustrations. Publisher's two-color Constructivist beveled black cloth. The six articles include Klutsis' "Photomontage as a New Kind of the Agitational Art," on pp 117-32.
2. KLUTSIS, GUSTAV GUSTAVOVICH, and ALEKSEI ELISEEVICH KRUCHENYKH. 1886-1968. Priemy Leninskoy rechi. [Studies of Lenin's Language]. Moscow: Izdanie Vserossiiskogo Soiuza Poetov, 1928. 8vo. Third printing. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by Klutsis. One of 1,000 copies.
3. KULAGINA, VALENTINA NIKIFOROVNA; and ALEKSEI ELISEEVICH KRUCHENYKH. Chernaya taina Esenina [Esenin's Black Secret]. 12mo. Moscow: published by the author, 1926. Frontispiece portrait of S. Esenin by Kulagina. Publisher's Constructivist tan wrappers designed by Kulagina.
4. ---. Liki Esenina [Esenin the Hooligan]. Moscow: Published by the author, 1926. 8vo. 2 portraits by Kulagina. Publisher's Constructivist tan wrappers designed by Kulagina. Cover detached.

Latvian-born Klutsis was one of the greatest of Soviet photocollagists, most famous for his posters extolling the virtues of Lenin and Stalin. While he propagated the role of the noble male Worker during the Five Year Plan, his wife Kulagina did the same with the female. But his Constructivist agitational propaganda fell out of favor and he was arrested and executed in 1938. Kulagina sought in vain for years to find out what happened to him. Klutsis was not rehabilitated until 1956.

LARIONOV, MIKHAIL FEDOROVICH. 1881-1964.
Vystavka kartin Futuristy, Luchisty Primitiv 1914 [Exhibition of Pictures by Futurists, Rayonists and Primitives]. Moscow: March-April 1914.
8vo. Introductory note by M. Larionov. 14 photogravure illustrations and one line illustration. Rebound in brown cloth. Exhibition "No. 4" organized by M. Larionov and N. Goncharova.

Larionov was one of the most important artists of the pre-Revolutionary Russian Avant-garde. He and his life-long partner, N. Goncharova, straddled the radical theories (represented by Cubo-Futurism and Rayonism) and Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. They settled in France in 1915 and never returned to Russia.

LISSITZKY, EL. 1890-1941.
ERENBURG, ILYA. 1891-1967. Moi Parizh [My Paris]. Moscow: IZOGIZ, 1933.
Oblong 8vo. 121 photogravure illustrations by I. Erenburg and two photomontages by El Lissitzky. Oblong 8vo. Original color Constructivist boards designed by Lissitzky. Edges rubbed.
WITH: Zapisky poetov [Notes of a Poet]. Moscow: GIZ, 1928. 12mo. Original two-color photomontage Constructivist wrappers designed by Lissitzky. Edges rubbed.

Russian writer Erenburg's Paris was not the conventional City of Lights beloved by American tourists. Instead he concentrated on the workers and derelicts he found in the streets with snapshots that Lissitzky turned into a highly charged album of political photomontages of this other Paris.

LÉGER, FERNAND. 1881-1955.
ERENBURG, ILYA GRIGOREVICH. 1891-1967. A Vse taki ona vertitsa [And All the Same the World Goes Round]. Moscow and Berlin: Gelikon, 1922.
12mo. Photogravure and line illustrations. Publisher's Cubist white wrappers designed by Fernand Léger. Wrappers worn and soiled.
WITH: ERENBURG, ILYA GRIGOREVICH. 1891-1967. Angliya [England]. Moscow: Federatsiya, 1931. Publisher's two-color Constructivist tan wrappers designed by Pavel Kharybin. Some wear, soiling.

French painter Léger is one of the most recognizable artists of the 20th Century for his individual form of Cubism or "Tubism," as some critics called it. The Russian Revolution and its impact on Modern Art fascinated him. Writer Erenburg was just one of the Russians Léger met in Paris. Another was Leon Trotsky while he was living in exile in Montparnesse prior to the Revolution. The Bolshevik was intrigued by Léger's proposal to refigure Moscow with streets of different colors.

GOZZI, CARLO. 1720-1806. Printsessa Turandot [Princess Turandot]. Moscow and Petrograd: Gosizdat, 1923.
Folio. 34 color and black-and-white plates. Original color lithographed wrappers designed by Nivinskii. Rebacked with small tears on front wrapper; lacking back wrapper.

A commemorative volume of Gozzi's 18th century play, famous as the basis for Puccini's final unfinished 1926 opera that became a Russian Avant-Garde spectacle under Lenin's regime. Soviet painter and architect Nivinskii's sets and costumes were originally designed for the 1922 production directed by Evgeny Vakhtangov from his hospital bed for the Third Studio of the Moscow Art Theatre.

MAYAKOVSKY, VLADIMIR VLADIMIROVICH. 1893-1930. Mayakovsky ulybaetsa Mayakovsky smeetsya Mayakovsky izdevaetsya [Mayakovsky Smiles, Mayakovsky Laughs and Mayakovsky Mocks]. Moscow and Petrograd: KRUG, 1923.
8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist white wrappers and printer's device on half-title page designed by Rodchenko. Wrappers worn.
WITH: Tuda i obratno [There and Back]. Moscow: Federatsiya, 1930. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by Rodchenko. Wrappers foxed; spine partially split.

Mayakovsky, the Poet of the Russian Revolution, often collaborated with the great Constructivist artist Rodchenko. They were both important practitioners of agitational propaganda and produced many politically inspired publications. They belonged to LEF [Left Front of the Arts], devoted to "re-examine the ideology and practices of so-called Leftist art, and to abandon individualism to increase art's value for developing Communism." Neither Lenin nor Trotsky really understood Mayakovsky's poetry, but when he committed suicide, Stalin declared, "Indifference to his work and memory is a crime."

RODCHENKO, ALEKSANDR MIKHAILOVICH. 1891-1956.
3 titles, Including:
1. KIRSANOV, SEMEN ISAAKOVICH. 1906-1972. Poslednii sovremennik [The Last Contemporary]. Moscow: Federatsiya, 1930. 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by Rodchenko.
2. TCHENG, SOUMAY. 1891-1959. Kitayanka Sume-Cheng [Soumay Tcheng the Chinese Woman]. Moscow: GIZ, 1929. 8vo. Photocollage illustrations by Rodchenko. Translated from the French by Mared Olenina. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by Rodchenko.
3. PERTSOV, VIKTOR OSIPOVICH. 1898-1980. Literatura zavtrashnego dnya [The Literature of Tomorrow]. Moscow: Federaytsiya, 1929. 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by Rodchenko.

Rodchenko was one of the monumental figures in the Russian Avant-Garde. He left his stamp on modern painting, graphic design and photography. He is perhaps best known for his Constructivist Avant-Garde designs for Soviet books, magazines, posters and advertising.

7 publications, including:

2. LEBEDEV, VLADIMIR VASILEVICH. 1891-1967; and SAMUIL YAKOVLEVICH MARSHAK. 1887-1964. Mister Tvister [Mr. Twister]. Kiev: OGIZ, 1933. Square 16mo. Black-and-white lithographic illustrations. Original color lithographed wrappers designed by Lebedev. First German edition.

4. CHEKHONIN, SERGEI VASSILOVICH. 1878-1936; ABRAM EFROS; and NIKOLAI PUNIN. S. Chekhonin. Moscow and Petrograd: GIZ, 1923. 4to. Color and black-and-white plates. Publisher's decorated wrappers designed by Chekhonin.
5. BRODSKII, ISAAK IZRAILEVICH. 1883-1939. Isaak Izrailevich Brodskii. Leningrad: Izdanie Iubileinogo Komiteta, 1929. Photogravure illustrations. 16mo. Decorated white wrappers.
6. APELTIN, M., editor. Painting, Sculpture and Graphic Arts in the USSR. Nos. 9-10 (Oct. 1930). 8vo. Color and black and white illustrations (some tipped in). In English.
Condition varies. Sold not subject to return.

RUSSIAN ART THEORIES.
A group of 6 items, including:

6. SENKIN, SERGEI YAKOVLEVICH. 1894-1963; and GRIGORII ALESKSANDROVICH MEDINSKII. 1899-1984. Samstroi. Moscow and Leningrad: Gosudarstvennoe Izdatelstvo Khudozhestvennoi Literatury, 1932. 8vo. Original two-color Constructivist photomontage white boards designed by S. Senkin. Worn.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
RUSSIAN LITERATURE.
A group of 8 works,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVIST LITERATURE / A PRIVATE COLLECTION SOLD WITHOUT RESERVE
RUSSIAN LITERATURE.
A group of 8 works, including:
1. PASTERNAK, BORIS. 1890-1960. 1905-g [The Year 1905]. Moscow: GIZ, 1927. 8vo. Publisher's color Constructivist wrappers. Edges rubbed.
2. ERENBURG, ILYA GRIGOREVICH. 1891-1967. Lik voiny [The Face of War]. Moscow: Puchina, 1924. 8vo. Pages partially uncut. Two-color decorated white wrappers designed by Leonid Voronov. Wrappers worn.
3. LAVINSKY, ANTON. 1893-1968; and MAYAKOVSKY, VLADIMIR VLADIMIROVICH. 1893-1930. 13 Let raboty [Thirteen Years of Work]. N.p.: VEKhUTEMAS, 1921. 2 Volumes. Small 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers designed by A. Lavinsky. Soiled, wrappers worn. Dedicated to the author's lover and muse, Lily Brik.
4. DIUBIN, VASSILII VLASOVICH. 1901-1974. Navstrechu smerti [Towards Death]. Moscow: Federatsiya, 1931. 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist white wrappers. Some wear and discoloring of wrappers.
5. SLISARENKO, OLEKSA ANDRIIOVICH. 1891-1937. Poemi [Poems]. Kiev: Panfuturysty, 1923. 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist tan wrappers. Some wear.
6. SHAPIRSHTEIN-LERS, YAKOV EFIMOVICH. 1901-1976. Obtschestvennyi smysl russkogo literaturnogo futurizma [The Moral Meaning of Russian Futurist Literature]. Moscow: A. G. Mironov, 1922. 8vo. Foreword by Anatoly Lunacharsky. Publisher's Futurist decorated tan wrappers designed by A. Lopukhin. One of 2,000 copies.
7. SELVINSKII, ILYA. 1899-1968. Kommendant 2 [Commander of the Army 2]. Moscow and Leningrad: GIZ, 1930. 8vo. Publisher's two-color Constructivist white boards designed by Aleksandr Surakov. Covers rubbed; endpapers discolored.
8. ROK, RIURIK. 1899-1962. Ot Riurika roka chteniya [Readings from Rorick Rok]. Moscow: Kobo, 1921. 8vo. Publisher's Cubo-Futurist wrappers designed by Grigorii Miller. No. 15 of an undisclosed edition. Some wear.

Miscellaneous Russian literary works by such major modern writers as Mayakovsky and Erenburg; including one early work by Nobel Prize Winner Boris Pasternak, the author of Doctor Zhivago.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
RUSSIAN THEATRICAL MONOGRAPHS.
A group of 3 works,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVIST LITERATURE / A PRIVATE COLLECTION SOLD WITHOUT RESERVE
RUSSIAN THEATRICAL MONOGRAPHS.
A group of 3 works, including:
1. TUGENDHOLD, JACQUES. Alexandra Exter. Berlin: Sarja, 1922. Translated by Count Petrovsky-Petrovo-Solovovo. Small 4to. Illustrated with 40 color and black-and-white plates (some tipped in). Publisher's two-color Constructivist brown wrappers. Lower corner of front wrapper chipped.
2. BOBISHOV, MIKHAIL PAVLOVICH. 1884-1964. Zhivopis i teatr [Paintings and the Theater]. Leningrad: Izd. Akademii Khudozhesrv, 1928. 8vo. Publisher's two-color decorated wrappers designed by Iu. Skallinn. One of 1,100 copies. Minor wear.
3. SOVIET THEATER. TAM. Leningrad: SOKOL, 1929. Thin 8vo. Unpaginated. Publisher's two-color Constructivist off-white wrappers. With a photograph of the desk in the theater laid in at front. Wrappers worn, soiled.

From the very beginnings of the Bolshevik regime, the theater was crucial to the aims of Marxist agitational propaganda. It helped sell the Revolution to the Masses. Alexandra Exter was among the finest of the Russian Avant-Garde stage and costume designers.

SOVIET ART AND PROPAGANDA.

2. [SOVIET ART EXHIBITION CATALOG.] Katalog peredvizhnoi vystavkii: Zhivopis, risunok, grafika, plakat, tekstil [Traveling Exhibition Catalog of Painting, Drawing, Graphics, Posters and Textiles]. 3. SAMOKHVALOV, ALEKSANDR NIKOLAEVICH. 1894-1971; and V. OKHOCHINSKII. Plakat [The Poster]. Leningrad: Kh-vo Akademii Khudozhest, [1924]. 8vo. Photogravure illustrations and two color plates. Publisher's two-color Constructivist white wrappers designed by A. Samokhvalov.

3. SALMON, ANDRÉ. Art russe moderne. Paris: Éditions Laville, 1928.

lot_symbols.sLongDesc: Lot to be sold without reserve.

lot_info.sDesc: TELINGATER, SOLOMON BENEDIKTOVICH. 1903-1969. 3 works designed by Telingater,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
TELINGATER, SOLOMON BENEDIKTOVICH. 1903-1969.
3 works designed by Telingater,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVIST LITERATURE / A PRIVATE COLLECTION SOLD WITHOUT RESERVE
TELINGATER, SOLOMON BENEDIKTOVICH. 1903-1969.
3 works designed by Telingater, including:
1. FEINBERG, ILYA. 1880-1955. 1914-i, dokumentalnyi pamflet [The Year 1914: A Documentary Pamphlet]. Moscow: MTP, 1934. 8vo. Photomontage illustrations by Telingater. Embossed Constructivist black cloth designed by Telingater. Front inner hinges repaired or broken.
2. SEDELNIKOV, NIKOLAY ALEKSANDROVICH. 1905-1994. Geroicheskaya epopeya [The Heroic Epic]. Moscow: Pravda and TsK VKP(b) [CPSU], 1935. 4to. Photogravure illustrations (some tipped-in and colored). Publisher's silver-stamped Constructivist beige cloth. Some wear and discoloring to covers.
3. m. KUpriyanov, p. KRYlov. NIK. Sy. Sokolov. Otchetnaya vystavka za 6 let [Kukryniksy. The Report Exhibition for Six Years]. Moscow: Izogiz, 1932. 4to. Illustrated by the "Kukryniksii." Publisher's two-color Constructivist wrappers. Wrappers soiled, chipped.

Georgian-born S. B. Telingater was one of the great Soviet masters of agit-prop photomontage. His designs were often satirical in nature in the tradition of the great German political collagist John Heartfield. 1914-i, dokumentalnyi pamflet may be his masterpiece with its dizzying Constructivist interplay of flaps and fold-outs and photomontages and stunning black-and-red typography.
