lot_info.sDesc: ROSSETTI FAMILY. A group of items related to the Rossettis,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
ROSSETTI FAMILY.
A group of items related to the Rossettis,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
ROSSETTI FAMILY.
A group of items related to the Rossettis, including:
1. ROSSETTI, GABRIELE. Poesie Varie Pe'l Glorioso Monarca di napoli e di Sicilia Giuseppe Napaoleone I. Naples: Stamperia Simoniana, 1806. Contemporary calf and gray patterned boards. First edition of the earliest book of poems by the distinguished father of the Rossetti clan, published when Gabriele was only 23.
2. ---. Disquisitions on the Antipapal Spirit Which Produced the Reformation, etc. London: Smith, Elder & Co., 1834. 2 volumes. Half black calf and marbled boards. First edition.
3. ---. Versi. Lausanne: S Bonamice E. Compagni, 1847. Publisher's green wrappers with woodcut illustration/vignette of three Pre-Raphaelite female figures. First edition.
4. LYELL, CHARLES. The Lyrical Poems of Dante Alighieri. London: William Smith, 1845. Contemporary gray-green blindstamped cloth, lettered in gilt. Lyell was the godfather of Dante Gabriel Rossetti, whose given name was Gabriel Charles Dante Rosetti. After Lyell's death, his godson dropped 'Charles' and used the name Dante Gabriel Rossetti professionally from then on.
5. ROSSETTI, MARIA FRANCESCA. Exercises in IdiomAtic Italian. London: Williams and Norgate, 1867. Green blind-stamped cloth. First edition, first issue.
6. ---. A Shadow of Dante. Boston: Little, Brown & Co., 1900. Four plates and frontispiece. Publisher's turquoise cloth with black stamped designs on cover and spine, gilt lettering on cover, designed by Dante Gabriel Rossetti.
7. ROSSETTI, WILLIAM MICHAEL. Gabriele Rossetti, A Versified Autobiography. London: Sands & Co., 1901. Full-page photographic reproductions of portraits, artwork, etc. Publisher's brown cloth. First edition, number 914 of 1,000 numbered copies.
8. ---. [Presentation]. The Diary of Dr. John William Polidori. London: Elkin Mathews, 1911. Publisher's half cloth and gray boards, lettered in red. First edition, inscribed by William Michael Rossetti to his daughter on the front fly: "To Mary, my beloved Daughter and Dedicatee, W.M. Rossetti, May, 1911."

ROSSETTI, CHRISTINA. 1830-1894.
A group of her works, including many first editions and first appearances, comprising: The Prince's Progress. London: Macmillan, 1866. First edition, original uncorrected state. * Another copy, as previous. * Another copy, with rare misprint of page number on p 20. * Sing-Song. Boston: 1872. First American edition. * "A Bride Song," in: Argosy Magazine. London: 1875. The first appearance of this poem in print. * Seek and Find; A Double Series of Short Stories of the Benedicite. London: n.d. [1879]. First edition. * Verses. London: 1893. * Called to Be Saints. London: 1895. * Poems; New and Enlarged Edition. London: 1897. * Maude, A Story for Girls. London: 1897. First edition. * The Poetical Works of Christina Rossetti. London: 1904. * Macmillan's Magazine. November 1859-October 1861. 4 volumes with Rossetti poems, including "Up-Hill" (February 1861); "A Birthday" (April 1861); and "An Apple-Gathering" (August, 1861). First editions. * DETTI, RINA. Translator. Poesie D'Amore. Firenze: 1948. First edition.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
LETTER TO DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI ON PAINTING.
SMETHAM, JAMES. 1821-1889.
Autograph Letter Signed ("Jas Smetham") to Dante Gabriel Rossetti discussing painting techniques, 4 pp recto and verso, 8vo (180 x 115 mm), Stoke Newington N., December 20, 1864,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
LETTER TO DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI ON PAINTING.
SMETHAM, JAMES. 1821-1889. Autograph Letter Signed ("Jas Smetham") to Dante Gabriel Rossetti discussing painting techniques, 4 pp recto and verso, 8vo (180 x 115 mm), Stoke Newington N., December 20, 1864, leaves mildly creased and toned, together with 1 p Autograph Manuscript of William Michael Rossetti, identifying the writer and subject of the letter, n.d., upper right corner with loss just affecting first line of text.

James Smetham was a close member of the Pre-Raphaelite circle and a personal friend of Gabriel Rossetti. In addition to painting, Smetham also produced essays and art criticism before his final mental breakdown in 1877, leading him to live the rest of his life in seclusion. In this letter, Smethem discusses painting practices and techniques, and thanks Rossetti for sending him information on dealers. He writes that Rossetti's previous letter "led me to revise the idea ... of the use of water color as a medium of small designs ... I find that a watercolor design takes me twice or three times as long as one of these studies in oil." Smetham also comments on the affect the new art of Photography has had on painting: "I am almost free from anxiety as to market—a thing that since Photography walked off with portraiture I have often had to contend against."

7. and 8. Poems. and Ballads and Sonnets. Leipzig: 1873 and 1882. Tauchnitz editions. Bound in half calf over marbled boards, spines gilt.

ROSSETTI BINDING DESIGN.
SHELLEY, PERCY BYSSHE. 1792-1822.
Poetical Works of Percy Bysshe Shelley. London: Reeves and Turner, 1876-7.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
ROSSETTI BINDING DESIGN.
SHELLEY, PERCY BYSSHE. 1792-1822. Poetical Works of Percy Bysshe Shelley. London: Reeves and Turner, 1876-7. 4 volumes. 8vo. 3 frontispieces and 4 illustrations. Publisher's blue cloth, gilt flower and sun circle device on front cover, gilt bird and butterfly devices on the back cover, and gilt titles on the spine designed by Dante Gabriel Rossetti (Fredeman), some wear and soiling to cloth, spines sunned.
Provenance: Volumes II and III inscribed on endpaper, "With the Publisher's Compliments."
WITH: 1882 Supplement to Library Editions of 1876-7. 8vo. Publisher's vellum backed white cloth boards, with DGR design stamped in gilt.
Provenance: Holograph pencil gift inscription to Professor Fredeman, with his own small pencil notes on facing blank, "To Dick, the rarest of rare books, a gift from Robin, in appreciation of a fabulously interesting lecture at our B. M. [i.e. British Museum], 15 March, 1994." [i.e. Robin de Beaumont, noted collector of PRB, Victorian Literature, etc.]

RARE COMPLETE SET OF SHELLEY IN ORIGINAL CLOTH WITH DESIGN BY DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI. A note in pencil by Fredeman appears on front fly of Supplement: "A Rossetti binding initially used in smaller format on 1876 edition of Buxton Forman's 'Shelley' and in a modified form for 1881 edition. This 1882 is yet another variant in larger format. See Barbers' 'Rossetti, Ricketss, and other English Publisher's bindings of the Printer's Library. Dec., 1970."

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.
The Blessed Damozel. New York: Dodd, Mead and Company, 1886.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.
The Blessed Damozel. New York: Dodd, Mead and Company, 1886.
Folio (385 x 295 mm). 20 illustrations after drawings by Kenyon Cox, proof impressions on India Paper. Publisher's vellum, elaborated Pre-Raphaelite gilt cover, and spine design by Keynyon Cox, silk-backed endpapers.

A FINE COPY OF THE DELUXE EDITION OF COX'S 1886 BLESSED DAMOZEL, limited to just 35 copies with proof impressions and full vellum decorated binding by the artist. Following on Rossetti's most successful poem, Kenyon Cox's "Blessed Damozel" was a landmark in printing and publisher's bookbinding in the U.S. for the period, and served to advance both Cox's career as an artist, as well as further popularize the Pre-Raphaelites to a growing U.S. market.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
[ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.]
Certificate of Copyright document for The Blessed Damozel,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
[ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.]
Certificate of Copyright document for The Blessed Damozel, partially printed and accomplished in manuscript, 1 p, 4to, Washington D.C., November 16, 1886, numbered 25892, with Copyright Office embossed stamp at upper left, signed by A.R. Spofford, Librarian of Congress. Folded into thirds, slight separation at ends of fold creases, toned.

Submitted by the Publisher of the U.S. edition of The Blessed Damozel, Dodd Mead and Company, the certificate includes the subtitle "With drawings by Kenyon Cox." Originally published in The Germ in 1850, Rossetti's most famous poem went through a number of textual revisions and re-publications during his lifetime. The publication date of this edition, 1886, coincides with the Berne Convention, and a change in the way U.S. publishers treated works by British and foreign authors.

13 volumes of posthumous printings: House of Life. Boston: Copeland and Day, 1894. Publisher's boards. Inscribed by George H. Ellwanger: "To William Sharp, artist of the Beautiful, from G.H.E., Rochester, May, '94." * The White Ship. Boston: William G. Colesworthy, The Cornhill Press, 1896. Publisher's boards. Number 320 of 450 copies. * Hand and Soul. London: Hacon and Ricketts, Vale Press, 1899. Publisher's boards. Decorations by Charles Ricketts. * Lenore by Gottfrid August Burger, Translated from the German by Dante Gabriel Rossetti. London: Ellis and Elvey, 1900. Publisher's buckram. Translation by DGR done in 1844, when he was 16. Provenance: William J. Fredeman. * The New Life of Dante Alighieri. New York: R. H. Russell, 1901. Publisher's wrappers. * Hand and Soul. London: De La More Press, 1902. Publisher's green goatskin over boards, gilt. * The Blessed Damozel. London: De La More Press, 1908. Publisher's soft blue leather over boards, gilt. * The House of Life. New York: Dodge Publishing Company, [1903]. Full blue leather with bold gilt-stamped Arts& Crafts strapwork design by Adrian J. Iorio on front cover, signed with his monogram, "AI." * The Staff and Scrip. London: Messrs. Ellis at the Chiswick Press, 1908. Publisher's wrappers. Provenance: William J. Fredeman. * The Ballad of Jan Van Hunks. London: Printed for Private Circulation Only [T. J. Wise], 1912. Publisher's wrappers. Scarce Thomas Wise printing, noted on verso of p 19: "London:/ Printed for T. Watts-Dunton, The Pines,/ Putney Hill, S. W./ Edition limited to Thirty Copies." * Taglialatela, Eduardo, trans. Dante Gabriele Rossetti: Rosa Maria, La Nave Bianca, etc. Roma: Casa Editrice Vallardi, n.d. ca. 1913. Publisher's wrappers. * Hand and Soul. Maastricht: The Halcyon Press, 1923. Publisher's cloth, glassine. * Ballad of Jan Van Hunks. London: George G. Harrap and Co., 1929. Publisher's vellum over boards, number 66 of 620 copies, signed by the illustrator Monro Orr.

AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.
A group of items related to the art and design of Dante Gabriel Rossetti:
1. Autograph Letter Signed ("D.G. Rossetti"), to his publisher Frederick Startridge Ellis regarding his Ballad & Sonnets, 1 p, 12mo, n.d. [c. 1881]. "Dear Ellis, I wrote to Mr. White a little more than a week ago, saying that I had some idea of deferring part of the Ballad & Sonnets [underlined] lot.... I now find that I shall be deferring it for the present, and that I may perhaps be ?? modelling a portion of the book, of course at my own expense."
2. ROSSETTI FAMILY. Rare compendium of mostly Gabriel Rossetti first editions, all complete with wrappers, some with presentations, including: Discorso Inaugurale, PRESENTED BY GABRIELE ROSSETTI TO HIS WIFE FRANCESCA, AND ADDITIONALLY INSCRIBED BY WILLIAM MICHAEL ROSSETTI, "W.M. Rossetti from Christina's Books, 1894"; "Medora e Corrado," lyrics by Gabriele Rossetti, music by Cipriani Potter; "Il Corsaro," lyrics by Gabriele Rossetti, music by Cipriani Potter; other works of a later date, some inscribed to Henrietta Rossetti, the owner of the compendium with her monogram signature and date 1919 in front. Polished buckram with gilt lettering Miscellaneous Rossetti, etc." on spine.
3. Hand and Soul. London: [Chiswick Press] At the sign of the Unicorn, 1900. Calf.
4. Pictures and Poems. New York: R. H. Russell, 1902. Folio. Publisher's red-brown buckram with elaborate gilt-embossed cover design consisting of strapwork floral pattern. First edition thus.
5. GRANT, HERBERT. Odes of Horace. London: Harrison & Sons, 1885. Publisher's green cloth with GILT STAMPED DESIGN ON COVERS AND SPINE DESIGNED BY DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI. First edition, presentation copy with slip pasted in.
6. FORMAN, H. BUXTON. The Poetical Works of Percy Bysshe Shelley. London: Reeves and Turner, 1888. 2 Volumes. Publisher's smooth brown buckram with GILT STAMPED DESIGN BY DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI. Second edition.
7. Royal Academy of Arts, Winter Exhibition, 1883; Special Selection from the Works of John Linnell and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. London: Wm. Clowes and Sons, 1883. First Edition.
8. Catalogue of the Remaining Works of the Painter and Poet Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Deceased; Comprising a few specimens in oil and water color; and numerous works in Crayons, Colored Chalks, Pen and Ink, Indian Ink, Pencil, etc. London: Christie, Manson & Woods, 1883. First edition. Printed wrappers.

prev_lot.desc: ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882. 13 volumes of posthumous printings:

next_lot.desc: ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882. Five items of secondary material on Dante Gabriel Rossetti and his work:

lot_info.sDesc: ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882. Five items of secondary material on Dante Gabriel Rossetti and his work
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.
Five items of secondary material on Dante Gabriel Rossetti and his work:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL. 1828-1882.
Five items of secondary material on Dante Gabriel Rossetti and his work:
1. Mourey, Gabriel. Rossetti et Les Preraphaelites Anglais. Paris: Librairie Renouard, Henri Laurens, ca. 1909. Publisher's wrappers, with red designs, lettered in black. Full-page photographs of paintings by Pre-Raphaelite artists.
2. Rossetti, Helen M. The Life and Work of Dante Gabriel Rossetti. London: The Art Journal Office, 1902. Publisher's cloth, central gilt emblem and gilt lettering to cover, gilt edges, illustrated yellow endpapers.
3. Rossetti Family. Bound collection of Dante Gabriel Rossetti related material, morocco-backed pebbled cloth, "Dante Gabriel Rossetti" on spine: a) excerpt from "Life of William Blake," b) Gallery No. V, Exhibition Catalogue, 1883, 29 pp, annotated (with pencil references to each entry), of DGR paintings, with copious and detailed notes in the description explaining composition, history of painting, etc. c) Catalog of the Remaining Works of the Painter ... Dante Gabriel Rossetti ... Christie, Manson & Woods, May 12, 1883. 19 pp, with reference numbers in marginalia (pencil). d) Catalogue... Pictures in Oil ... formed by that well-known amateur, William Graham, April 2 and 8, 1886, containing copious paintings by Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Edward Burne-Jones, with detailed descriptions and explanations in each entry.
4. Baildon, H. Bellyse, ed.] The Round Table Series. Edinburgh: William Brown, 1887. Publisher's green cloth, cover stamped in black. Contains long essays on Rossetti, Ruskin, Elliot and a few others. Essay on Rossetti's appears at end, and was the work of Peter Walker Nicholson.
5. Tirebuck, William [Edward]. Dante Gabriel Rossetti: His Work and Influence. London: Elliot Stock, 1882. Publisher's dark green cloth, gilt, gilt edges, cream endpapers.
The first book-length study of Dante Gabriel Rossetti as a painter-poet. Fredeman lists the title (30.1), but it is one of his rare, unannotated entries, indicating he never saw a copy. Extremely scarce. Jerome McGann in his book, "Victorian Connections," gives this fascinating report regarding the book's reception by his Watts: "...published in October ... William had not involvement. Watts was furious that his proprietary claims were being usurped, and, calling Tirebuck an 'ass' and his book a 'baby-like production,' warned William that 'a lot of fellows will scribble about him and vulgarize his name.'" However, McGann goes on to add, "but William could not have but been that the unknown author had referred to Dante Gabriel as 'the most influential of the much-talked-of Brotherhood."

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:

ROSSETTI, WILLIAM MICHAEL. 1829-1919.
A group of publications and letters, including:
1. Timerius: A Drama, by Francis Adams. London: T. Fisher Unwin, 1894. Publisher's white buckram. Inscribed on front flyleaf: "W. M. Rossetti, from the Publisher, 1894. First edition. Copy number 3 of a limited edition of 250.
2. Ruskin, Rossetti, Preraphaelitism. London: George Allen, 1899. 4to. Publisher's beige and olive green cloth. First edition, number 147 of an edition of 250.
3. Democratic Sonnets. London: Alston Rivers Ltd., 1907. 2 volumes in 1. Publisher's beige buckram. First edition.
4. Autograph Letter Signed ("W.M. Rossetti"), to Dr. Moore, 2pp, London: December 7, 1890. With envelope.
5. Autograph Letter Signed ("W.M. Rossetti"), to the Editor of Art Journal, 1 p, 12mo, London: January 15, [1907?].
6. HUTCHINSON, THOMAS. Autograph Letter Signed, to William Michael Rossetti, 3 pp, 8vo, Northumberland, May 4, 1905.
7. Pre-Raphaelite Diaries and Letters. London: 1900. Blue cloth gilt.
8. A volume of family offprints bound together, labeled "Miscellanies."

lot_info.sDesc: FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895. Autograph Letter Signed (Em. F.), to her cousin Emily, regarding a plan to market and advertise her work,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895.
Autograph Letter Signed ("Em. F."), to her cousin Emily, regarding a plan to market and advertise her work,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895.
Autograph Letter Signed ("Em. F."), to her cousin Emily, regarding a plan to market and advertise her work, 3 pp recto and verso, 8vo, London, February 12, 1863, on pale blue paper with embossed crest on p 1. Fold creases, slight browning.
WITH: Autograph Note, to the publisher of The Rock, requesting a copy of the November 20th issue, 1 p, 8vo, n.d., on letterhead of the Victoria Press, written formally in the third person.

In the lengthy letter to her cousin, also named Emily, Faithfull suggests that they can market her work by sending out title pages as advertising leaflets: "I will send the parcel to you at Norwood, but I shall detain it ... in order to send you 500 title pages with a first sentence to the Reader ... if you will send this widely it will be a good thing & you might at once send them to the Clergy on the list you have obtained ... and if we send the title page out, we are sure of orders...." The book in discussion is probably A Welcome: Original Contributions in Poetry and Prose, which was published by her Victoria Press, in 1863.

next_lot.desc: FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895. Autograph Letter Signed ("E. Faithfull") to Wallis MacKay

lot_info.sDesc: FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895. Autograph Letter Signed (E. Faithfull) to Wallis MacKay
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895.
Autograph Letter Signed ("E. Faithfull") to Wallis MacKay
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
FAITHFULL, EMILY. 1835-1895.
Autograph Letter Signed ("E. Faithfull") to Wallis MacKay 4 pp recto and verso, 8vo, New York, 1872, written during her last visit to the United States, on her letterhead with lion crest printed in brown at upper left of p 1. Fold creases, smudges, slight red ink stain, tape adhered to verso of last page.

In the fall of 1872, Faithfull writes from New York City to Irish-born writer, journalist and cartoonist for Punch, Wallis MacKay (1852-1907): "New York Hotel. Friday. Dear Mr. MacKay, Most heartily do we wish you both a pleasant voyage across the 'cruel cruel sea' & a speedy return to this 'great country.' Of course, you couldn't spend yr last eve in N.Y. in listening to an English lecture, tho' I keep strictly to the hour...." Faithfull mentions MacKay early in her book, Three Visits to America (1884), regarding his visit to New York and the squalor he found there. Her visits to America, along with her lectures, are fully chronicled in her book, but her legacy as reformer and outspoken critic of the poor, disenfranchised and marginalized citizens of the "free world," serves as an indelible historical imprint.

next_lot.desc: HUNT, WILLIAM HOLMAN. 1827-1910. Group of 4 Autograph Letters Signed (all "W. Holman Hunt"), including:

lot_info.sDesc: HUNT, WILLIAM HOLMAN. 1827-1910. Group of 4 Autograph Letters Signed (all W. Holman Hunt), including
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
HUNT, WILLIAM HOLMAN. 1827-1910.
Group of 4 Autograph Letters Signed (all "W. Holman Hunt"), including:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
HUNT, WILLIAM HOLMAN. 1827-1910.
Group of 4 Autograph Letters Signed (all "W. Holman Hunt"), including:
1. Letter to an unknown recipient, probably a printer or engraver, 2 pp, recto only, 8vo, London, December 13, 1859, saying "I ought to have acknowledged the receipt of your kind note — with the three papers for my selection and the wood blocks to make my drawings upon...." Stains to verso of last page bleeding through to text on recto, slight soiling along fold crease.
2. Letter to Ernest Gambart (art dealer) inquiring about "... one Rothschild, an exhibition agent once, as he represents, in your employ, and still in your high commendation," 1 p, 8vo, London, June 30th, 1864. Fold creases, browning at edges.
3. Letter to Mrs. Hunt (wife of painter Alfred William Hunt), thanking her for her letter concerning his controversial second engagement, 1 p, with signature on second page, 8vo, n.p. [London], June 24, 1873. Fold creases.
4. Letter to Alfred William Hunt ("My dear Hunt"), thanking him for offering a studio, 3 pp recto and verso, 8vo, London, August 30th, 1874, in a warm and chatty tone: ""I have been suffering a great deal of annoyance from having to go all the way to West End near Highgate to my work — of late the difficulty has been increased by annoyance that I suffer when there...." Fold creases, minor spotting.

Pre-Raphaelite painter William Holman Hunt was married first to Fanny Waugh, who died in childbirth while they were living in Italy. He later became engaged to Fanny's youngest sister Edith, but because it was illegal in England to marry the sister of a deceased spouse, the couple was married in Switzerland. The marriage alienated the couple among members of the extended family.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
NESBIT, EDITH. 1858-1924.
A Pomander of Verse. London: John Lane at the Bodley Head, 1895.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
NESBIT, EDITH. 1858-1924.
A Pomander of Verse. London: John Lane at the Bodley Head, 1895.
8vo. Woodcut vignette on title page, woodcut vignettes in text. Publisher's tan cloth decorated in gilt. Sunned, corners and spine ends bumped, text block slightly separated at center, one leaf (pp 69-70) creased at top margin, scattered browning and spotting.

FIRST EDITION, INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR on the free front endpaper: "Olindo Malagodi, from E. Nesbit." The woodcuts are by Laurence Housman, and are echoed in the design of the gilt stamping on the upper cover. The inscription is to Olindo Malagodi (1870-1934), Italian socialist writer and later politician. Edith Nesbit expounded Socialism early on, was an active member in the Fabian Society, and a close follower of William Morris.

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
PATMORE, COVENTRY. 1823-1896.
4 books, with an Autograph Letter Signed:
1. Poems. London: Edward Moxon, 1844. 8vo. Publisher's green cloth with blind-stamped design on both covers. With 8-page prospectus at front dated March 1, 1847. FIRST EDITION.
2. Marriage in May Fair; or, The Comedy of Real Life. London: Reynell and Weight, 1853. 8vo. Half red morocco, marbled boards with original wrappers bound in. FOR PRIVATE CIRCULATION, PRESENTATION COPY: "To J. Buckstone, Esq. with P. Geo. Patmore's Compts."
3. The Angel in the House. London: John W. Parker, 1854. Publisher's cloth, printed title label. FIRST EDITION.
4. Religio Poetae, Etc. London: George Bell and Sons, 1893. Publisher's cloth, printed title label. FIRST EDITION, inserted slip, "With the Author's Compliments." Provenance: John Dennis, noted author and poet (bookplate).
WITH: Autograph Letter Signed to Mr. Rawlins, 1 p, asking him to review a legal document, "Can you look in tonight to tell me what it all means..." etc. Patmore letters are quite scarce. Provenance: William Fredeman Pre-Raphaelite Collection.

AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
PATMORE, COVENTRY. 1823-1896.
Faithful For Ever; An Episode. London: John W. Parker, 1860.
Small 8vo (160 x 100 mm). Contemporary three quarter vellum and marbled boards, marbled endpapers. Upper cover slightly bowed, soiling to covers, scattered browning and spotting, especially to flyleaves and title page.

FIRST EDITION, INSCRIBED to English poet and patron of literature Richard Monkton Milnes: "R.M. Milnes, esq., from Coventry Patmore." Milnes advanced the careers of Tennyson and Emerson in Britain, and was one of the earliest champions of Swinburne, as well as Patmore, whom Milnes had secured a long-standing tenure at the British Museum.

PATMORE, COVENTRY. 1823-1896.
Amelia. London: George Bell and Sons, 1878.
8vo (177 x 115 mm). Publisher's blindstamped cloth, title label to spine, some rubbing to label, some sunning to covers.
Provenance: Harriet G. Robson (Patmore's third wife, her signature to the title page); John Drinkwater (signature to the first blank, dated 1920, provenance note in his hand beneath, his bookplate); J.O. Edwards (booklabel).

FIRST EDITION, THE PATMORE FAMILY-JOHN DRINKWATER COPY, noted on the first blank by Drinkwater: "The first edition, perfect, as issued. H. G. Robson, whose autograph is in the title-page, was the lady who became the third Mrs. Patmore. The notes on pp. 222 ["not in 1890 edition,"] and 228 ["See 'Open Secret' in 1890 edition], seem to be in her writing. From the Patmore library."

next_lot.desc: PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD. A group of secondary material related to the pre-Raphaelites:

lot_info.sDesc: PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD. A group of secondary material related to the pre-Raphaelites
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD.
A group of secondary material related to the pre-Raphaelites:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD.
A group of secondary material related to the pre-Raphaelites:
1. YOUNG, REVEREND EDWARD. Pre-Raffaellitism. London: Longman, Brown, Green, Longmans and Roberts, 1857. Publisher's cloth stamped in black. First edition. E. T. Cook's Copy, the biographer of Ruskin, who edited the 39-volume edition of his writings. Written in pencil on front pastedown, "E.T. Cook," and a later bookseller's notation on next page with an arrow labeled "Assn. Copy."
2. BUCHANAN. ROBERT. The Fleshly School of Poetry and Other Phenomena of the Day. London: Strahan and Co., 1872. Publisher's printed wrappers with engraved illustration on cover of wild garlic, hound's tongue, etc. (odiferous flowers). First edition. Celebrated and influential, if not scathing treatise accusing the Pre-Raphaelite artists of immorality, and perhaps helping to increase their exposure through subsequent dialogues. With autograph letter by Buchanan asking a Miss Marie de Hey if she would like to purchase Madcap Prince for her own use... "I fancy the part would suit you, and the piece is light and effective enough. Or I could arrange with you for a new picturesque narrative drama for starry purposes." Some tears in ALS, corners of book slightly ben and covers only faintly age-marked, ese very good or better.
3. ANON. The Battle of the Petticoats. A Satire. London: James Clarke & Co., 1874. Printed light blue wrappers. A satire, presumably about the excesses of opulent attire in the Church of England, all in the guise of poetry, with copious notes. First edition.
4. QUILLER-COUCH, ARTHUR. Green Bays: Verses and Parodies. London: Methuen, 1893. Light green cloth with leaf and vine motif stamped in dark green. First edition. Parodies on artists and poets of the day including Algernon Swinburne, Tennyson, and others.
5. EULENBERG, HERBERT. Die Pra-Raphaeliten. Dusseldorf: P. Clasen, n.d. [c.1900]. 12mo. Four photographic illustrations (on two pages) of paintings by Rossetti and Burne-Jones. Cream printed wrappers with Art Nouveau cover design.
6. WOODS, MRS. MATTHEW. Some Women of the Pre-Raphaelite Movement. Philadelphia: The Browning Press, [1914]. Original gray paper printed wrappers. First edition. Scarce booklet on the women of the Pre-Raphaelite Movement, a paper read at the closing meeting of the Philadelphia Society of Arts and Letters in April, 1914. Original yarn ties. Cover detached. Scarce.
7. BROWN, OLIVER MADOX. The Dwale Bluth / Hebditch's Legacy. Ed. by William M. Rossetti. London: 1876. Modern half calf.

next_lot.desc: PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD. Six illustrated works from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood artists:

lot_info.sDesc: PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD. Six illustrated works from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood artists
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD.
Six illustrated works from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood artists:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD.
Six illustrated works from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood artists:
1. [BROWN, FORD MADOX.] Winkworth, Catherine. Lyra Germanica. London: Longman, Green, Longman and Roberts, 1861. Wood-engraved plates by John Leighton, Ford Madox Brown and others. Publisher's brown cloth with elaborately gilt design, gilt edges, by John Leighton. Fine. Fredeman 91.1.
2. [HUGHES, ARTHUR.] Tennyson, Alfred, Lord. Enoch Arden. London: Moxon, 1866. Engraved portrait frontis after Woolner, engraved plates after Hughes. Publisher's blue cloth, elaborately gilt, recased.
3. [HUGHES, ARTHUR.] Tennyson, Alfred, Lord. Enoch Arden. London: Moxon, 1866. Engraved portrait frontis after Woolner, engraved plates after Hughes. Publisher's green cloth, with elaborate gilt designs both covers and spine, expertly rebacked. First American edition.
4. [PATON , J. NOEL.] Coleridge, Samuel Taylor. Rime of the Ancient Mariner. London: Art-Union of London, 1863. Oblong elephant folio. Lithographed title page, and 20 wood-engraved plates after Paton. Publisher's maroon flexible cloth boards, gilt design and lettering on cover.
5. [ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL], et al. Tennyson, Alfred, Lord. Poems. London: Edward Moxon, 1857. 4to. Engraved portrait frontispiece, from a medallion by Woolner, 54 wood-engraved plates by by the Dalziels, W.J. Linton, etc after D.G. Rossetti, J.E. Millais, W. Holman Hunt, etc. Publisher's green cloth, gilt. The famed Moxon Tennyson, widely considered the earliest and most important representative illustrated edition featuring Pre-Raphaelite art in a large format.
6. [ROSSETTI, DANTE GABRIEL], et al. Tennyson, Alfred, Lord. Poems. London: Edward Moxon, 1861. Publisher's deluxe binding with elaborate gilt-stamped floral design on both covers and spine, "Routledge & Co." on spine. A second copy of the seminal Post-Raphaelite production, in a rare deluxe binding variant.
7. MOXON, EDWARD. ALS to B.R. Woodward, 3 pp, 8vo, London, March 5, 1867.

lot_info.sDesc: PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD. A collection of 20 items, being books and autograph letters related to the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD.
A collection of 20 items, being books and autograph letters related to the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
PRE-RAPHAELITE BROTHERHOOD.
A collection of 20 items, being books and autograph letters related to the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood:
Bell, Malcolm. Edward Burne-Jones, A Record and Review. London: 1897. FLORENCE CAMM'S COPY, calligraphically signed, "Florence Camm, August, mcmxxi." * BURNE-JONES, EDWARD. The Legend of St. George and the Dragon. London: 1895. Publisher's printed wrappers, headpiece design, printed ad back of rear wrapper. Also contains extracts of poems by WILLIAM MORRIS. * ---. The Drawings of Sir Edward Burne-Jones. London: [1907]. Publisher's cloth-backed boards, dust-jacket. * SHIELDS, FREDERICK, illustrator. Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress. London: 1864. Folio. Publisher's cloth. * ---. Autograph Letter Signed to Robert Falkner, 2pp, on mourning stationery, Mummyfield, Merton, May 11, 1897. "For 'auld lang Syne' I know you will see my nephew-, who is lacking employment. * ---. Autograph Letter Signed to Robert Falkner, 3 pp, 16 June, 1897, a follow-up to the previous. * ---. Autograph Letter Signed, To Editor of Life, 1 p. * Hueffer, Ford Madox. Ford Madox Brown: A Record of His Life and Work. London: 1896. Publisher's illustrated boards. * Hueffer, Ford Madox. Catalogue of an Exhibition of Collected Works by Ford Madox Brown. London: 1909. Publisher's wrappers. * BEDDINGTON, MAUD, illustrator. Triolets & Other Songs. London: [c.1913]. First edition. Publisher's wrappers. * DALZIEL, GEORGE. Mattie Grey and Other Poems by GD. London: 1873. INSCRIBED BY DALZIEL. * SEVERN, WALTER, illustrator. Houghton, Lord. Good Night & Good Morning. London, n.d. (ca 1880). * MCCABE, JAMES D. Dowie Dens o' Yarrow. London: 1860. Large folio. 6 proof engravings, mounted. * Ford, Julia E. Simeon Solomon, An Appreciation. New York: 1908. Publisher's cloth. * SCOTT, WILLIAM BELL. Illustrations to The King's Quair. Edinburgh: 1887. Original card covers, roughly rebacked. * SAME. A Poet's Harvest Home: Being One Hundred Short Poems... London: 1893. Publisher's buckram cloth. * Trevelyan, P.J. Fragment of Autograph Letter From Lady Trevelkyn with drawing of Hedgehog to William Bell Scott, "I remain dear Mr. [drawing of hedgehog] yrs sincerely, P. J. Trevelyn. Cou's love. She says you are not to be insulted." The hedghog was William Bell Scott's fond cartoon symbol. * WATTS, GEORGE FREDERICK. Autograph Letter Signed to Mr(s) Thompson, 2 p. * ---. Autograph Letter Signed, 2 pp, Jan. 27, 1895: " my sincere desire has always been that Art should take its place as a factor in real education and general improvement and I think 'new directions' of your efforts extremely important and valuable." (With book label "From the Library of H. C. Marillier, Kelmscott House, Hammersmith.") * SHIELDS, FREDERICK. Chapel of the Ascension. Ed. by Hall Caine. London: 1902.

[Works of John Ruskin.] New York: John Wiley & Sons, 1873-1884.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
RUSKIN, JOHN. 1819-1900.
[Works of John Ruskin.] New York: John Wiley & Sons, 1873-1884.
25 volumes. 8vo. Publisher's green cloth, gilt decorated covers and spine, stamped in red and gold.

SCARCE PUBLISHER'S UNIFORM CLOTH ISSUE OF RUSKIN'S WORKS, not mentioned in this format in bibliographies. The set includes (from spine titles, volume numbers are supplied): (1) Love's Meinie and Proserpina (1873); (2) The Laws of Fesole and Art in England (1879); (3) Arrows of the Chase (1881); (4) Pre-Raphaelitism and Aratra Pentelici (1882); (5) The Poetry of Architecture (1883); (6) Unto This Last and Munera Pulveri (1883); (7) Time and Tide and Political Economy of Art (1883); (8) Crown of Wild Olive and Queen of the Air (1883); (9) Eagle's Nest and Frondes Agrestes (1883); (10-14) Modern Painters (1884) in five numbered volumes; (15-17) Stones of Venice (1884) in three numbered volumes; (18) The Two Paths and Lectures on Art (1884); (19) Fors Clavigera (1884); (20) Elements of Drawing and Elements of Perspective (1884); (21) Ariadne Florentian (1884); (22) Seven Lamps of Architecture and Lectures on Architecture and Painting (1884); (23) Sesame and Lilies and Ethics of the Dust (1884); (24) St. Mark's Rest and Deucalion (1884); (25) Poems and Mornings in Florence (1884).

lot_info.sDesc: SANDYS, FREDERICK. 1829-1904. A Consideration of the Art of Frederick Sandys. London Archibald Constable and Co., 1896.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
SANDYS, FREDERICK. 1829-1904.
A Consideration of the Art of Frederick Sandys. London: Archibald Constable and Co., 1896.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
SANDYS, FREDERICK. 1829-1904.
A Consideration of the Art of Frederick Sandys. London: Archibald Constable and Co., 1896.
Folio (273 x 275 mm). Publisher's beige cloth, gilt-blocked designs on upper cover, light soiling, title page pulling.
DELUXE LARGE PAPER COPY, number XII of an unstated number of copies specially bound and numbered in roman numerals to half-title. Superbly illustrated with plates of Sandys' work, including three photogravures.

WITH: Autograph Letter Signed ("Fredk Sandys") to William Michael Rossetti on a new painting he would like Gabriel and Michael to see, 2 pp, with additional note, 182 x 113 mm, bifolium, 1 Spencer Street, Victoria Street, Friday [July 17, 1774,] folds.

A FINE LETTER "DEAR ROSSETTI," FROM SANDYS, asking after Gabriel and discussing a new painting. Sandys was a famed Pre-Raphaelite painter, illustrator and draughtsman, who was closely allied with the PRB. In part, "I have a portrait of a fearful old woman I want him to see and tell me about- I want you to see it also- will you come any day before Wednesday... There is an awful lot of work in the picture in fact it consist entirely of caps — cap strings and white stomacher-...."

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
SCOTT, WILLIAM BELL. 1811-1890.
The Year of the World; A Philosophical Poem. London: William Tait, 1846.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
SCOTT, WILLIAM BELL. 1811-1890.
The Year of the World; A Philosophical Poem. London: William Tait, 1846.
8vo (220 x 138 mm). Half-title. Contemporary red textured cloth, titled in gilt on spine. Corners rubbed, soiled, scattered spotting and foxing.

FIRST EDITION, WITH PRESENTATION INSCRIPTION on the half-title: "Mary Armstrong, from the Author." This copy does not contain the illustrations. The publisher ran out of illustration plates near the end of the press run, but continued assembling copies without them. No priority as to issue or state has been determined regarding the absence of illustrations. Curiously, this example contains the holograph corrections on p 11, but the correction on p 63 is truncated, only crossing out the word "formed" and and adding the word "and" just after "Things arcane."

SHARP, WILLIAM. 1855-1905.
Two fine association copies of Sharp's poetry:
1. Romantic Ballads and Poems of Phantasy. London: Printed for the Author by Walter Scott, 1888. 8vo. Publisher's parchment over boards, lettered in red and black to cover.
FIRST EDITION, PRESENTATION COPY, INSCRIBED BY SHARP TO WILLIAM BELL SCOTT: "William Bell Scott with the kindest regards and friendliest remembrance of the Author."
2. The Human Inheritance, the New Hope, Motherhood. London: Elliot Stock, 1882. 8vo. Publisher's green cloth, gilt, decorated endpapers.
FIRST EDITION OF HIS FIRST BOOK OF POETRY, PRESENTATION COPY, inscribed: "To Frederick Langbridge, in slight return for his charming, 'Songs in Sunshine,' W.S. 82."
Sharp was a noted Scottish writer of poetry and became a well-respected critic and biographer, writing under the psedonym, Fiona MacLeod. He was a closely allied to the Pre-Raphaelite movement, and especially to Dante Gabriel Rossetti.

SWINBURNE, ALGERNON CHARLES. 1837-1909.
Poems and Ballads. Second Series. London: Spottiswoode and Co. for Chatto and Windus, 1878.
8vo. Tipped-in presentation slip inscribed "From the Author" mounted on an 8vo leaf at front. Brown morocco gilt by Otto Zahn for Toof & Co. (signed with both names and dated 1906 on the front turn-in), elaborate gilt vine decoration, spine with 5 raised bands, gilt dentelles, marbled endpapers, top edge gilt, publishers upper cover and spine cloth bound in at back. Upper cover detached, uniform toning throughout.
WITH: Autograph Letter Signed ("AC Swinburne"), to an unnamed "descendant of Admiral Collingwood," apologizing that he is not well enough to receive visitors, 1 p, 8vo, London, February 15, 1908, fold creases. Loosely inserted in book.
Provenance: George A. Zabriskie (1868-1954, bookplate with presentation inscription dated 1945).

FIRST EDITION, in an Arts & Crafts era binding by Otto Zahn, the German binder who had worked for Zaehnsdorf and eventually became President of Toof & Co. in Memphis, Tennessee.

lot_info.sDesc: TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892. Two poetical works, in uniform bindings,
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892.
Two poetical works, in uniform bindings,
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892.
Two poetical works, in uniform bindings, including:
1. Poems, Chiefly Lyrical. London: Effingham Wilson, 1830.
2. Poems. London: Edward Moxon, 1833.
Both 8vo (164 x 104 mm). Rebacked contemporary maroon textured calf, gilt decorative borders, marbled endpapers and edges. Some chips and gouges to covers; foxing, especially to flyleaves.

FIRST EDITIONS IN A MATCHING SET. Charles Merivale's copies, both with his ownership signature. Poems, Chiefly Lyrical with first issue error, on page 91 (mis-numbered as "19"), and eratta slip at end, without ads. Poems with "Ouverie" Street imprint on verso of title-page. Merivale was a noted English historian and churchman, and main founder and promoter of the famed "Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race" which took place at Henley in 1829. His principal work, A History of the Romans Under the Empire, was published in eight volumes from 1850 to 1862.

lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892.
Four Tennyson-related items:
1. Autograph Letter Signed integrally ("Lord Tennyson") 2 times, a note to Francis Overend White, 2 pp recto and verso, 8vo, Surrey, July 2, 1886, on black bordered mourning stationery, light toning and thumbing, small closed tears at horizontal folds. In part: "Lord Tennyson begs to thank Mr. White for his kind letter. He would have much pleasure in possessing Archbishop Tenison's life: & be grateful to Mr. White for the act of sending it to him.
2. Franking Signature ("Tennyson") on Autograph Transmittal Envelope addressed to Her Royal Highness the Crown Princess of Prussia at Osborne, n.p., n.d., on mourning stationery, lightly thumbed.
3. Albumen print portrait of Tennyson, London: April 15, 1861, a carte-de-visite, publisher's imprint at lower mount, bookseller's ticket to verso,
4. Manuscript fair copy for "Davy and the Dignified Flunkey," 16 lines in Frederic Tennyson's hand.

Poems, Chiefly Lyrical. London: Effingham Wilson, 1830.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892.
Poems, Chiefly Lyrical. London: Effingham Wilson, 1830.
Large 12mo (179 x 108 mm). 20th century brown morocco elaborately gilt by Bradsteet's of New York (signed on front endleaf), top edge gilt, gilt dentelles, brown endpapers. Slightly rubbed and bumped, scattered spotting.
Provenance: Dr. Henry M. Garsson (his binding, with gilt embossed name on upper cover).

FIRST EDITION, FIRST ISSUE, with p 91 misnumbered as "19," and with the scarce errata leaf and two-page advertisement at end. "Carcanet" is spelled correctly on p 72 (a second state point). This is Tennyson's first regularly published book. Henry M. Garsson (1896-1983) founded a conglomerate of munitions businesses in 1941 together with his brother. After the war, they were convicted of bribing a congressman and defrauding the U.S. government on wartime munitions contracts. Wise 7.

Payment for purchases may be made in or by (a) cash, (b) cashier's check or money order, (c) personal check with approved credit drawn on a U.S. bank, (d) wire transfer or other immediate bank transfer, or (e) Visa, MasterCard, American Express or Discover credit, charge or debit card for returning clients only. For information and estimates on domestic and international shipping as well as export licenses please contact Bonhams Shipping Department.

prev_lot.desc: TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892. Poems, Chiefly Lyrical. London: Effingham Wilson, 1830.

next_lot.desc: TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892. 6 items:

lot_info.sDesc: TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892. 6 items
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892.
6 items:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
TENNYSON, ALFRED, LORD. 1809-1892.
6 items:
1. Ode on the Death of the Duke of Wellington. London: Edward Moxon, 1852. 8vo. Original printed light blue wrappers. Light spotting to prelims, cover mildly toned. First edition.
2. Maud, and Other Poems. London: Edward Moxon, 1855. 12mo (170 x 102 mm). Original blindstamped green cloth. With 8 pp of ads at the front dated August 1855. Inked annotations to last poem correcting "The Charge of the Light Brigade" to its final version. Penciled note on first ad page mentions book is from the Mortimer Collins collection, and edits are likely his.
3. Anon. Anti-Maud. London: L. Booth, 1856. 12mo. Rebound in half calf. 2nd edition. A spoof of Tennyson's famous poem.
4. Poems. MDCCCXXX. MDCCCXXXIII. [Toronto]: Privately printed [for James Dykes Campbell], 1862. Small 8vo (165 x 134 mm). Original printed blue wrappers, uncut and unopened. Consists of the suppressed poems of Tennyson from Poems, Chiefly Lyrical (1830) and Poems (1833).
5. A Welcome. London: Edward Moxon & Co., 1863. Bifoliate leaf (170 x 108 mm).
6. RUPPRECHT, GEORG. Tennysons Naturschildrerungen. Leipzig-Reudnitz, 1893. 8vo (230 x 140 mm). Printed wrappers. Doctoral dissertation on Tennyson.

lot_info.sDesc: WISE, THOMAS J. 1859-1937. The Ashley Library A Catalogue of Printed Books, Manuscripts and Autograph Letters Collected by Thomas James Wise. London Printed for Private Circulation, 1922.
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
WISE, THOMAS J. 1859-1937.
The Ashley Library: A Catalogue of Printed Books, Manuscripts and Autograph Letters Collected by Thomas James Wise. London: Printed for Private Circulation, 1922.
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
WISE, THOMAS J. 1859-1937.
The Ashley Library: A Catalogue of Printed Books, Manuscripts and Autograph Letters Collected by Thomas James Wise. London: Printed for Private Circulation, 1922.
11 volumes. 4to (250 x 193 mm). Illustrated. Original beige buckram gilt. Some sunning and thumbing to cloth.
Provenance: Robert Arundell Hudson (bookplate).
WITH: ALS of Wise to Hudson thanking him for the return of a pamphlet, February 4, 1926.

A fine set of Wise's catalog of his remarkable collection of poetry and literature, his bibliographic accomplishments marred by his double life as a forger and a thief.

next_lot.desc: WOOLNER, THOMAS. 1825-1892. 5 items by or to Woolner:

lot_info.sDesc: WOOLNER, THOMAS. 1825-1892. 5 items by or to Woolner
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
WOOLNER, THOMAS. 1825-1892.
5 items by or to Woolner:
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF PRE-RAPHAELITE LITERATURE
WOOLNER, THOMAS. 1825-1892.
5 items by or to Woolner:
1. Autograph Letter Signed ("Thos: Woolner"), asking his correspondent if he has primary materials that will help William Rossetti as he finishes his Life of Blake, 1 p, 8vo (185 x 111 mm), Newcastle on Tyne, January 3, 1868, light toning.
2. Tiresias London: George Bell and Sons, 1886. 8vo. Red cloth gilt. Presentation copy, with printed "From the author" slip tipped in to front flyleaf.
3. My Beautiful Lady. London: MacMillan and Co., 1863. 8vo. Brown cloth gilt. First edition, annotated in pencil (by the author) with notes toward a revised edition.
4. My Beautiful Lady. London: MacMillan, 1866. 8vo. Blue cloth gilt. Third edition, presentation copy, signed by Woolner to Professor Selwyn, 1868 on the half-title, and with an ALS of Woolner to Selwyn dated 2/16/68 presenting the book laid down to front endpaper.
5. HARTE, BRET. On the Frontier. Boston: Houghton, Mifflin and Company, 1884. Small 8vo. Rebound in crushed red morocco gile with green and blue onlays by GAZ.
6.---. Autograph Letter Signed ("Bret Harte"), thanking Woolner for sending a copy of his latest and chiding him for not signing the volume, 3 pp recto and verso, 8vo (200 x 125 mm, conjoining leaves), Glasgow, Scotland, July 29, 1884, on Consulate of the United States letterhead. Harte served as US Consul from the 1870s to 1885 before returning to writing full time.
